Posts.Content: Usually stage 1 & 2 patients can opt. for lumpectomy with rad. etc.  Do you have a strong familiar history of BC?  This could change things.  Get a second opinion, 3rd if necessary before going through this most radical procedure.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: recurrance

Posts.Content: Hi!  I read your e-mail.  What may be happening here is your grandmothers age.  One doctor may be saying she is fine because he doesn't care to put her through all the surgery, treatment etc. when it may not really help.  This may be one of the reasons another doctor is sending her to a cardiologist, to see if her heart would withstand a surgical procedure of this nature.  Someone should be with your grandmother when she goes to the doctor's, to ask the questions for her so they can explain to her what is going own and then decide as a family or with grandmom if you care to put her through this.  You want to know what she will really gain.  Years of a quality life??  As far as people and so called friends, I agree with one of the responses.  You get to know who really cares when you're put through something like this.  Unfortuately, it can be a painfull experience when your friends or family drop off to the waste side because they are too busy and can't deal with your problems.  I guess we just have to forgive them but never forget how important it is for us to be there for others.  Good luck with your Grandmother.  She is lucky to have a granddaughter like you who cares so much.
Posts.Title: I need advice

Posts.Content: With DCIS the surgeon may or may not be able to get clear margins.  This is crucial that they obtain healthy tissue completely around the area.  If it can not be achieved then a mastectomy will have to be performed.  I had stage 1 BC.  It derived from a DCIS but broke through and became invasive.  I had the same options and choose the lumpectomy with radiation.  As mine was left sided there is the question of the heart hit by the beam but I used an experimental technique using a breathing mechanism that removes, in some cases all of the heart, in mine a small area was still exposed. I had this done over 5 years ago.  The one thing to consider with radiation is tha, as they say, it is the gift that keeps on giving.  It will continue to cause shrinkage of the breast tissue over time.  My surgeon intitially told me that once you have radiation you cannot have reconstruction but I fought for that as I lost quite a bit of tissue from an already modest breast.  I've had implants for 4 years now and have had to the affected breast tweeked once but I'm very pleased with the results.  Would you consider reconstruction if you opt for mastectomy??  Considering the DCIS is in two different quadrants of the same breasts this should prompt you to find out what the resultant cosmetic appearance may be.  This may influence you decision.  Get as much info as possible so you feel comfortable in your decision.  Know what they have in mind as far as extent of surgery in either case.  Again, with DCIS there is the possibility of not achieving clear margins and then the decision would then be mastectomy.  Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: lumpectomy vs mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi!  I had a similar experience with a bone scan.  Shortly after being diagnosed with stage l BC and being reassured about the 90+ cure rate, I had a bone scan and areas on my spine lit up.  It took another 6 weeks of follow up tests and consultations with a few oncologic radiologist to determine that is was not related to my BC although the initial reading from the radiologist indicated probable mets.  A second and 3rd scan at a later time showed an area on my left rib and two additional areas on my right rib.  This was all confusing to my oncologic team.  After conferring with one another they decided not to take any more scans unless I was having symptoms as there were too many false positives. An MRI also indicated I had a 90% probable malignancy in the opposite breast which turned out to be benign.  My experience is that these tests are extremely sensitive and will show previous scar tissue, degeneration, bone healing processes etc. so it may very well be related to something other than mets.  Hope this helps!
Posts.Title: seen the dr. today, now I'm confused?

Posts.Content: My understanding is that this is still considered local even with two nodes involved.  You have a chance at full recovery at this stage (1 & 2) with proper treatment.  Particulary your PET and follow up scans do not show evidence of disease spread so it should be aggressively treated at this point to provide the best chance of cure or long term survival.  I would seek a second even 3rd opinion at this point and be a part of the decision process for your care.  I've been told cure no longer applies if it is found to have spread beyond the breast and local nodes to bone or other organs although I work with a women whose sister was diagnosed with stage 4 almost 20 years ago and is still doing fine.  She went to NY and deals with a alternative medicine doctor which obviously has worked for her.  This however is not the norm with stage 4 but shows that anything is possible.  Best of luck!
Posts.Title: SO Scared!

Posts.Content: I have been on Femara (a similar drug) five years this February.  There has been no mention of stopping.  A woman I work with has been on it about 6 years and again no mention of stopping.  I do know that Tamoxifen should only be taken for 5 years because after that time it can actually have adverse effects and many women are then put on Arimdex or Femara but I don't know if there have been studies to show whether it loses it's effectiveness etc.  Until my doctor says otherwise I will continue to use it.
Posts.Title: Arimidex--stay on or quit?

Posts.Content: Hi Mom!  I don't have much information for you but I read your posting and I can't believe what your young 16 year old daughter has already been through.  I was recently diagnosed with thyroid cancer and had breast cancer diagnosed almost 4 years ago and in speaking with a genetic counselor there are syndromes that link various problems.  They can be inherited or occur in utero.  One such syndrome that was mentioned is Cowden syndrome, this links breast, thyroid problems not necessarily cancerous but can be, kidney and skin lesions.  As far as teens with breast cancer, I did meet a 22 year old woman who was diagnosed with BC.  That has been the youngest I have encountered.  I would hope that her doctor's are moving if for no other reason because of her young age to rule out or take care of her problem.  I know how terrifying this must be for you.  I have two daughters.  My heart goes out to you and her.  I will say a prayer for the best outcome with this new problem.  Best wishes!
Posts.Title: Breast cancer in Teens

Posts.Content: That's amazing.  God certainly works in mysterious ways.  I recently sent a thank you note to my 83 year old mom who was making herself sick over my situation.  I told her that it had made me stronger and that I felt that sometimes God uses our circumstance for his purpose.  Sounds like that is what happened here.  Truly she must be His child.  Best of luck to the both of you.  I certainly hope that all turns out well.
Posts.Title: Breast cancer in Teens

Posts.Content: Your guardian angel was with you and your doctor on that day.  And for the doctor to have the presence of mind to check both breast with MRI was your life saver obviously.  I know it is too easy to think about the what ifs.  Actually when I was first diagnosed with stage 1 BC, some micro calcifications that had been there prior had increased somewhat in number and were beginning to form a pattern although, as the radiologist indicated, if you look at each calcification in its self they are round and don't look suspicious.  His gut feeling sent me to biopsy indicating he has to send sometimes 20 women in to find the 2 that will be positive.  I was pretty confident going in as I had a false alarm that turned out to be fibrocystic disease which is fairly common.  He told me he would say I only had about a 5 to 7% chance of being malignant.  Guess what, I was 1 of the 2 so there you go.  I was fortunate as well.  About a year or so earlier when I had my scare I actually had my films and could see tiny bubbles forming within the duct close to the nipple of the left breast but no one was alerted at that time by that formation as they were concentration on the right breast.  Low and behold the cancer actually was in the area of the tiny bubbles on the left side.  So did I actually see the insitu? as pathology inidcated it occurred from an insitu.  Scarry!  Last year I had a follow up MRI which showed a 80% probable malignancy on the right side which was biopsied but it was benign so now my doctors are relunctant to do MRI's unless otherewise indicated.  It is not an easy process, cancer is so unpredictable at times.  But, I'm so glad you are doing so well and had you cancer treated early.  I'm also fortunate.  God bless you with continued good health.
Posts.Title: Be your own advocate

Posts.Content: Best of luck at the Cancer Center.  Maybe once you have had your work up etc. you can let others know about your experience.  I believe they are at the cutting edge of science so hopefully you will be one of their success stories. God Bless!
Posts.Title: Chemo not working, anyone experience this?

Posts.Content: I have extremely sensitive skin so before starting radiation therapy my radiologist gave me Biofene for radiation care.  It is a cream and they were happy to see how well my skin faired from treatment.  It is a prescription so mention it to your doctor for a script.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Message: Radiation burns

Posts.Content: I read you story, so sorry you are going through this. Tamoxifen has been on the market for about 30 years and has been used by early stage breast cancer patients, it actually was the "gold standard" until additional drugs in different classes starting hitting the market such as Arimidex and Femara. Tamoxifen is the only one I'm aware of for premenapausal women. It works by blocking estrogen from the breast acting as a receptor in the breast. Estrogen has been known to fuel breast cancer and may be indicated in it's development although no study clearly shows that. It is suggested that some premenapausal women have their ovaries removed in order to stop the main production, however, the body makes estrogen even after menapause, lower amounts of course. Tamoxifen has proven to help prevent the occurrence and recurrence in both breasts. There was actually a program being developed to give younger women who are at high risk, particulary daughters of breast cancer first degree relatives,tamoxifen to see in fact if it actually prevent or delay the onset. Don't know what happened to the study or if it is ongoing. Losing both breasts and going through reconstructive surgery is a big ordeal, physically and emotionally, of course, in some cases of breast cancer the woman doesn't have a choice. I guess what your doctor is saying, in a case where there is no cancer tamoxifen may work to prevent or delay. As long as careful monitoring continues and I'm sure it will it may be a viable option. If you ever have any doubt you should always seek a second or third opinion if necessary. It that way you will feel more comfortable with you decision and that is important because living with breast cancer and your choices can be tough. Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: Tomoxofen as Cancer Prevention

Posts.Content: Hi!  What is your age and do you have any history of bc?  Lymph nodes are very small and normally wouldn't stand out alone unless there were some abnormality from my understanding.  In matter of fact, that is precisely what my doctors look for in my follow up visits, any enlarged lymph nodes.  If it were me I would opt for some type of biopsy.  It does not have to be excisional were they remove the entire specimen, getting some cells may be telling enough.  Six months may or may not be a long time.  I had an indeterminate linear appearing lesion that after 6 months and another 6 months they still couldn't decide if it were benign or not.  I asked my surgeon if any bc can be so aggressive as to spread beyond the breast in a 6 month period and he said yes, it is possible.  That is all I needed to know.  By the way, that specimen was benign, but I went on to develop breast cancer 3 years later in the opposite breast and I have no history of any breast cancer in my family.
Posts.Title: Result from latest exam

Posts.Content: How are you feeling physically at this point??  I contacted the Cancer Treatment Center also at one point and my insurance which is an HMO would not cover services.  But you should call them about a consult, however, they may require their own testing so if your ins. does not cover prepared to pay for their services.  They were able to give me a ball park figure over the phone.  Have you considered any BC trials??  I would definitely look to see if any are being conducted with your stage cancer.  I have read in CURE magazine where some people have responded well in trials.  Research is working on finding tests that determine who will benefit and from what chemo agent so people are not put on a drug with side effects that will not benefit their cancer.  They are doing this to try to find the right "cocktail" so to speak to address an individuals tumor.  Unfortunately, all this takes time that is why I would suggest a trial.  May God bless you.  Enjoy each day as life is precious.  Hope you are feeling well so you can engage.
Posts.Title: Chemo not working, anyone experience this?

Posts.Content: I just wanted to put this out there.  I recently went back for my year mammo and my doctor had ordered both a mammo and ultrasound.  I am a BC patient and have implants which make it somewhat more dificult to monitor with mammo.  Well, after my mammo the radiologist suggested everything looked stable and questioned why my doctor was ordering an ultrasound.  Usually they only use this to check on something that shows up in mammo is what she had relayed.  After discussing it with her she  indicated she would leave it up to me.  To make a longer story short, the ultrasound showed a questionable cyst that I'm scheduled to have FNA.  Pending on whether it can be aspirated or not or what it shows, I may also need biopsy.  I did some research on this and found due to my age, my BC history, the small size of the cyst it definitely warrants further investigation.  My point if I had said oh, my mammo is find, okay I'll pass, I would have been sent out the door to return in one year.  That may have been a big mistake.  If you are postmenapausal and have small cysts with certain properties within it, it warrants further investigation and mammo's are not used to pick up cysts.  Don't be afraid to question, question, question and speak to your doctors.
Posts.Title: Be your own advocate

Posts.Content: I'm sorry you have come across such arrogant doctors in your treatment of DCIS.  I had stage 1 BC almost 5 years ago.  I know a woman who was diagnosed with DCIS and after two attempts at removal they could not obtain clear margins and performed a radical mastectomy and she is disfigured at her upper chest and has a large sunken hole under her arm and is so uncomfortable wearing even a semi low cut dress or sleeveless.  So it is no joke.  What if it were his wife?? or daughter or sister, mother etc.  When I was deciding treatment a friend said to me to ask them what would they advise if it was their loved one so I did just that.  I must say my surgeon stopped and I saw his eyes ponder a moment and then he spoke.  Don't miss your follow up due to arrogant, non caring doctors when there are ones out there that do understand and care.  My team of doctors, an oncologist, a surgeon and my radiation oncologist are great.  I can call them anytime even 5 years out and they will get back to me ASAP.  I even contacted them when I was diagnosed with thyroid cancer a year ago and they got information for me so their  are caring health professionals out there.  You may want to deal with a breast surgeon or a female doctor in the future but definitely not the one who feels DCIS is of no significance.
Posts.Title: Should I worry about this....

Posts.Content: Jodie, I'm so sorry.  You were doing well and then this.  Yes, this is can be a very unpredictable disease.  I understand cancer has two main modes of spread, one through the lymphatic system and the other through blood.  It is possible to have a microscopic cell pass through the lymph system even before dissection.  I understand with breast cancer  all you need is one cancerous cell to start the process.  This is what we all face the possibility it will return and have spread.  I don't know anything about the treatment at this point or how successful it can be but certainly pursue any options and look into clinical trials.  I have read stories where some people have responded well in trials.  My heart goes out to you Jodie and may God give you the strength, courage and guidance to help you through this so you can find joy in your life again soon.
Posts.Title: It is breast ca. mets..now what?

Posts.Content: I take Femara.  Have been on it for about 3 & l/2 years and have had no side effects.  It is an anti-estrogen drug.  Unlike Tamoxifen, however, it can deplete bone so it can contribute to osteoporosis.  You may need to increase your calcium and vit. D levels.  It is usually used as an adjunct therapy after surgery, radiation and chemo if needed.  Hope this helps!  Also, I work with a woman who also is on Femara and has had no side effects as well.
Posts.Title: New Drug Info please

Posts.Content: My bc was on the left side and only 4mm so that in self doesn't mean anything as far as cells left behind.  My doctor explained it only takes one micro cell to cause a problem.  They do have a new breathing apparatus for left sided bc pioneered at Jefferson Hospital in PA.  I was one of their first candidates.  It moves the heart away before radiation when it is administered.  In my case a small portion of the heart was still exposed but with some, depending on the automical placement of your heart and the the tumor placement of the breast, the entire heart can be spared.  They also have a more targeted radiation therapy since I had mine 5 years ago and instead of going in every day for 7 weeks and it can be done, I believe in a weeks time or so.  I would get a second opinion with a good radiation oncologist before I would forego this treatment.  My surgeon told me I could either have a mastectomy or lumpectomy with radiation.  Radiation is actual the completion of the later. Again, if you think that only one cell is needed to start a process that can spread beyond the breast and once this occurs the average life span is two years.  Of course, some have lived with metastatic disease longer but why not do everything possible to prevent this occurence.  I am glad that you are tolerating the Arimedex well.  It definitely has been shown to REDUCE the risk of recurrence in the breast and other areas of the body.  Before you forego radiation please get as much info again from a radiation oncologist specialist.  They can give you a good estimate of the actual % of benefit in your particular case.  Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: foregoing radiation- maybe arimidex too- help!

Posts.Content: Hi!  I read your post.  I had stage 1 BC 5 years ago and my surgeon indicated to me that they will take enough tissue to obtain clear margins entirely around the tumor but there is always a possibility of micro cells present.  This is the reason for radiation to sort of clean up the area.  Radiation to the breast is not bad if you use some precautions to minimize redness and irritation.  I have been taking Femara which is in the same class as Arimidex witout any side effects.  Another woman I work with was on Tamoxifen for 5 years and Femara just over 5 years, again with no adverse side effects.  You may also be one of the lucky ones that can tolerate it and also benefit if your BC was estrogen/ progesterin positive.  My surgeon put it this way, you be as aggressive as you need to be at the onset because once the "horse is out of the barn" so to speak, the chance of cure is gone and it is about prolonging life.  Better to work on cure than find out it has spread beyond the breast as there is no turning back.  I agree you have to be comfortable with your decision ultimately.  Best of luck!
Posts.Title: foregoing radiation- maybe arimidex too- help!

Posts.Content: Hi!  It has been over 4 years since I had to post for myself in this regard.  Just went back for my first 12 month mammo which actually showed everything to be stable.  An ultrasound however showed a complex cyst 5 mm in the opposite breast.  I'm in my late 50's.  I had many cysts from time to time when younger and about a year ago had an area behind a simple cyst that was biopsied and benign.  What is concerning is it has some properties within the oval cyst which make it somewhat suspicious. I'm scheduled for a FNA hoping that is shows clear fluid and disappears entirely or biopsy will be indicated.  I'm going in the hospital the following day for a neck dissection related to thyroid cancer that was diagnosed last year.  I have been trying to stay positive as I have been thus far able to live a normal life, and I remind myself of all the really bad situations out there but sometimes it just gets to be much.  Just needed a forum to speak.  Anyone going through a similar experience with the cyst, I would love to hear from you.  Thanks!
Posts.Title: complex cyst?

Posts.Content: From the information you furnished mastectomy would appear to be the only viable treatment.  Your surgeon must attain clear margins around the original site for lumpectomy to be successfull.  Radiation is only used for microscopic disease that may or may not be present.  Reconstuction is available to any woman who opts for it.  It many cases it can be done at the same time of surgery or at a later time.  You can discuss this with your doctor.  It is always good to have a second opinion.  This will either confirm or give you other alternatives but in your case I believe they may concur with your original doctor, but this alone may help you to have confidence in your decision.  Best of luck.  Treating the cancer at this point is critical.  The fact that it hasn't spread to your nodes is promising but only one cell needs to leave the site for mets to organs or bone and then there is no longer a cure at this time once that occurs.  Breast cancer is nasty and you want to treat it as aggressively as possible from day one in hopes of having the best outcome.
Posts.Title: mastectomy or not

Posts.Content: I've been on Femara for over 3 years and have been fortunate enough to have done well with no side effects but many do not.  Maybe you can talk to you doctor about switching to Tamoxifen.  It works in a different way and may not have the same side effects as Arimidex or Femara as they are a similar acting drug.  It would be better than stopping these drugs all together as it does offer good protection not as much as the newer drugs but it use to be the gold standard for years.  I believe Tamoxifen can be taken for 5 years.  By then something else may be available that is even better that more women can tolerate.
Posts.Title: Four years of Arimidex

Posts.Content: I also had a .4 or .5 mm ductal invasive carcinoma with no lymph node involvement.  I left the actual dosing and area to be targeted up to my radiation oncologist, but you can always seek a second opinion.  Radiation to the breast is not bad particulary if you see what head and neck people have to go through.  I had sensitive skin and informed my doctor.  She gave me Biafine radiation cream that can be used after each treatment and washed off just before your next treatment.  I started using it from the very beginning. The most I had was a pink breast that eventually faded, very little if any discomfort.  The doctors did comment on the fact that I fared very well.  I believe it was the cream.  You want to address any break off cancer cells anywhere in the breast, rather treat the breast and lessen the chance of cells migrating beyond to other organs or lymph.  Cancer cells travel through blood as well and you only need one cell to begin the process.  I have been breast cancer free for five years come October 2008.  Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: radiation therapy

Posts.Content: You are right to have questions.  I would suggest you seek a genetic counselor.  My BC team is at a large city hospital and they have a genetic counselor on staff who has been helping me at no charge.  You're right there is a connection between ovarian and breast with the BRAC l & BRAC 11 mutations.  You may want to consider having your ovaries removed.  I would ask about the benefits from this to your breast care person.  I was negative for that mutation but in following up on it many did opt to have a bilateral mastectomy for preventive measures.  Of course, this is extreme but not radical if your concern is great.  You should at the very least seek a second and possibly third opinion about your case so you can make an informed decision that you will feel comfortable with.  One last note, having a mastectomy does not insure a recurrence, however, it does cut down your risk tremendously.  There is always some residual breast tissue going up into the chest area that remains so follow up care is always indicated.  Best of luck!
Posts.Title: sentinal lymph biop. w/lumpectomy

Posts.Content: They can use MRI for dense breasts as well.  They can also do a needle biopsy to take some cells.  I had a 4 to 5 mm tumor (very small) that did not show up on mammo but I had microcalcifications that were encircling the tumor.  I had just been to my surgeon 6 weeks prior and he never felt the little bugger.  It turned out to be stage 1 BC which broke our from DCIS.  I had a lumpectomy, radiation and take Femara.  It has been 5 years and all is well.  The earlier it is caught the better your chances for a long productive life.
Posts.Title: Did anyone's cancer NOT show up on Mammogram or Ultrasound?

Posts.Content: Well mine showed up as microcalcium deposits on mammography.  I had some on a previous study but the radiologist saw what he felt might be a pattern starting even though the deposits themselves did not look suspicious (rounded).  He said there was a 1 & 1/2 chance in 10 that it indicated a breast cancer.  I was that 1 &/12.  Biopsy showed it was actually surrounding a small cancerous tumor that had broken through the duct.  Fortunately, I had a diligent radiologist and it was diagnosed as stage 1 with no positive detection in the lymph nodes.  That was 9 years ago.
Posts.Title: Did anyone's cancer NOT show up on Mammogram or Ultrasound?

Posts.Content: I certainly understand your anxiety.  I once was given a sedative before undergoing an MRI.  Doctor's seem so busy today and I'm sure for them one day just slips into the next etc. but I would mention to your doctor the anxiety you have in waiting for results.  If she or he has any compassion at all she will make a point for someone to call you when the results are in to hopefully relieve some of your stress.  I have always found that the unknown is worse then knowing even if the news is not so great.  It is difficult to live your life hanging on the balance each day.  I've have learned over the years, however, not to dwell on the what ifs and just do my routine visits etc. as if it were a normal part of living which it is for me, and let the doctor's deal with some of the stress.  When the news comes, good or bad, it comes eventually and I will deal with whatever at that time and in the meantime I'm bent on living each day.  Hopes this helps!
Posts.Title: Wait time for test results

Posts.Content: Don't give up on mom.  She must have had a biopsy right?  They've given her general anethesia for that.  How did she do??  Does she have any serious medical problems that might complicate surgery??  What type of surgery is being proposed?  a lumpectomy? or a mastectomy?  You should go with mom to the doctors and share any concerns about her up coming proposed treatment.  Sometimes you have options, like some stage l or stage 2 BC can choose lumpectomy with radiation and some suggest or choose mastectomy.  It is a lot to take in at first and that is why having a second pair of ears is always good when seeing the doctor and going over all this.  There are numerous woman living with a BC diagnosis, me for one.  It will be 5 years this September and I plan on going on for a long time.  This is the more difficult time because of all the unknown and questions that arise but once she is on her way with treatment things will settle down and I'm sure she will be well again.  Best wishes!
Posts.Title: Invasive Ductal Carcinoma

Posts.Content: I also wanted to add there is such a thing as a complex cyst which may have the components of a regular cyst and some indeterminate properties to it.
Posts.Title: Cyst in Breast

Posts.Content: I'm on Femara and take Zometa infusions.  Originally I was taking them every 4 months, now it is every 6.  I am fortunate enough not to have any lasting side effects from either medication.  Zometa is an IV form of Fosamax which like other new osteoporosis drugs on the market are taken orally, anywhere from every week or every month.  I believe there is a new one that can be taken less than that.  These are oral forms and if tolerated they are the first choice of treatment for osteoporosis.  Have you tried them?  I was on Fosamax but due to GERD (gasto distress symptoms) I could no longer take that.  I knew I had osteoporosis after a dexascan diagnosed it.  It is true the aromitase drugs deplete bone so your bone density should definetly be monitored.  Do you take calcium supplements?  And Vit. D supplements because calcium needs D to absorb?  Only if the oral form and supplements are not controlling your bone should you have to be on Zometa if indeed it is only being given to treat your osteoporosis that you do not know if you have?  I would first ask for a dexascan, a simple test that will tell you what your bone status is.  Based on that information you can discuss all options.  You definitely should be on calcium supplements and D.  Having Zometa every 3 months is rather aggressive also particulary if there isn't a documented problem.  Zometa is also used for bone spread as it stabalizes bone and recent published reports shows a positive effect on postmenapausal women with early BC as well which they were unaware of and further research is going on to determine if this is a course of treatment for some early BC.  But again, if it is not well tolerated you should discuss your options as there are some and demand a bone density so you know your bone status.
Posts.Title: Arimidex and Zometa

Posts.Content: I always try to interpret my test results as well because I don't trust most.  I looked it up, "hypo" means less or less amount; and "density" refers to the amount of tissue so it might imply tissue that is receded as the definition indicates.  It doesn't appear to be alarming, due to any cancer process but I'm only a lay person.
Posts.Title: Hypodensity near the distal esophagus and aorta

Posts.Content: I understand there is a new blood test, can't remember name, that can be given for early stage cancers to determine you response to chemo.  Some women will not respond to chemo and some will definitely benefit.  Ask your doctors, they should know about this.  It may or may not apply in your case but if the test determined no response you could avoid it altogether, however, if it showed a possible good response, I'm sure you would opt for it.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: cemotheropy or pills

Posts.Content: I know my sister had a cyst drained from her breast and it drained blood so the material had to be sent for biopsy.  In her case it was benign.  Sometimes there is something behind or around the cyst as well as in my situation, fortunately, in that case it was also benign.
Posts.Title: Cyst in Breast

Posts.Content: I probably would agree somewhat with the person who responded to "3rd opinion". You obviously do not feel comfortable with the situation. They should have followed up with an ultrasound as this seems to be where the lesion was seen initially, however, they can use MRI in conjuction with a mammo and ultrasound to better determine the need for biopsy. There is a fine line for radioligst between watching and sending women in for biopsy for many reasons. The bottom line however is that you don't feel comfortable waiting and doing nothing more, and this should be expressed to your doctors. They should work with you in making a determination of what this may at this time so you can feel comfortable in the ultimate decision to follow up or go in for biopsy and what kind. Good luck!
Posts.Title: 3rd Opinion?

Posts.Content: A PET scan is very sensitive but expensive.  I believe it would either eliminate or confirm any recurrence.  Why is he saying that it would not help??
Posts.Title: strange pains -concerned with reaccurance

Posts.Content: I developed edema in my breast after a biopsy and it turned out to be an infection even though I was not experiencing any pain just swelling.  Antibiotics took care of it.
Posts.Title: lymphedema

Posts.Content: Not familiar with your uncle's condition but I would agree with the other response and definitely pursue this.  Have you had any MRI's?  CT's, I believe are for bony structures, MRI's are for soft tissue.  How about a PET?  Something isn't quite right so you owe it to yourself to try to get to the bottom of it all.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: strange pains -concerned with reaccurance

Posts.Content: I don't know your age or familar history, if there is any breast or ovarian cancer, but another first indication of bc which can only be detected by mammo are microcalcifications.  Fortunately for me these microcalcifications were encompassing a small 4 to 5 mm tumor that had started as ductal in-situ and became invasive.  I was diagnosed with stage 1 with negative lymph nodes.  I had been examined by a surgeon just 6 weeks prior and he did not feel this tiny tumor, however, as someone else did mention, I did experience an odd painful discomfort in that area just prior to diagnosis.
Posts.Title: Symptoms of Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: I so understand your frustration.  You really have to be your own advocate when it comes to your health.  I'm going through a similar quandry but a different problem although I had BC over 3 years ago and went through radiation.  I don't understand you doctor telling your if you had recovered from the initial side effects of radiation, redness, itching, rash etc. for several months why he or she would attribute you new problem to the radiation.  I personally only experienced pink and some warmth in the area but I was also given radiation cream from the onset to help with this and as time went on this faded and the skin appeared and felt normal again.  I never suffered any breast pain only from surgery.  Are you seeing an actual breast surgeon?  Or a general surgeon?  Studies have shown that patients know their bodies best and when something doesn't feel or seem right it may not be.  Definitely, find a surgeon or oncologist who hears you and takes your problem seriously.  It needs to be checked further and sooner rather than later.  Yes, I have also heard that BC is more aggressive in black women so even more reason to stay on top of this.  You deserve to have the best treatment available and don't let any doctor push you off.  It is so easy to become just a number to them.  Someone once told me that when you question your doctors, do it in such a manner that you ask them:  if I were your wife, or your mother, sister etc., what would you recommend.  You'll be surprised how they shift gears and give it more thought.  Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: Can someone please give me some peace

Posts.Content: Hi Rett!  Your words were inspiring and brought tears to my eyes.  Your right, my sister recently told me that those of us who are willing to give to others in their time of need may not always be reciprocated in our time of need so to be carefull not to have the same expectations.  I know some people care but are just not able or willing to as your say "stretch their arms around someone else's pain".  I had an appointment just the other day with my medical oncologist and he said he was sorry to hear I had to go through my current situation with thryoid cancer, that it wouldn't be pleasant for me, he was sincere.  Sometimes that's is all it takes.  He mentioned he thought I appeared to be in good spirits and on past visits he was concerned because I seemed depressed.  The day I saw him I had just received a very awaited phone call from my endo and got some clarification as to what I might expect with my thryoid surgery and both he and my surgeon felt I would do well.  Since I had been so apprehensive about that, it was very relieving to get that news so I guess I had a good day when I saw him.  But there have been tough days as well.  I'm a good one for telling others that I'm supporting that your days are like the weather.  Yes, there will stormy days but there were also be sunny days and days in between.  I have to remind myself that it applies to me as well.  Let me know how your current situation is going.  What is in the planning as far as treatment or follow up for you?  Thanks again for writing!
Posts.Title: Can someone please give me some peace

Posts.Content: Thanks Rett!  You sound like a true soldier for the Lord.  My sister is actually a pastor but I have had difficulty at times with my relationship with the Lord.  Thought I was able to see and be a part of some of His workings in the past but had a situation which cast some confusion and doubt, maybe it was just in my interpretation.  I know He is there but for some reason I haven't been able to reach out as I should and it is not just because of the cancers.  People in my life have been disappointing and this has hurt maybe like l hurt Him by not being there.  Maybe that is what He wants me to feel and understand.  I'm sure I'll have plenty of time to ponder while recuperating from thryoid cancer surgery and preparing for treatment as I've learned it is a arduous process.  Have a blessed day!
Posts.Title: Can someone please give me some peace

Posts.Content: I just went back to your original posting that I read and I'm sorry you have already answered many of my questions in that posting.  I have been going back and forth to this blog and the thyroid blog and the melanoma blog as I have been diagnosed with all three and it gets confusing.  I see you not only have children but grandchildren and a husband.  I don't have any grandchildren but we do have a grand "dog".  I read your situation and all along you knew something wasn't right and no one listened.  We know our own bodies, why doesn't the medical profession listen to what we say.  They are so use to the "norm" they forget that there is always that exception.  I've been fortunate in that my breast cancer team does listen and allows me to be a partner in my care.  My thyroid team, however, associated with another hospital which has been publicised many times as a top notch facility can be a little pompous, (they know it all) and I have to keep pushing and questioning.  Forgive me for not remembering you situation.  Keep in touch!
Posts.Title: Can someone please give me some peace

Posts.Content: Good for you, party for me too!!
Posts.Title: Can someone please give me some peace

Posts.Content: A second opinion is always a good idea.  Where is your soon to be mother in law from?
Posts.Title: What hospital is the best equipped to treat breast cancer?

Posts.Content: Have you already been on Tamoxifen?  If not, this works in a different way than the drugs you mentioned and may be more tolerable.  It was the orignal anti-estrogen used.  Studies show that it is not as effective as the other drugs but does offer some protection.
Posts.Title: Side effects of Aromasin and Armidex

Posts.Content: I've been on Femara since March of 2004 and have had no side effects that I can attribute. I also work with a lady who has been on Femara slightly longer after coming off of 5 years of Tamoxifen and she also states no side effects. Both of us, however, are on medications for osteoporosis as Femara can deplete the bone somewhat. I have read where some women have experienced side effects of joint and muscle pain but maybe the counter osteoporosis medications has something to do with voiding any side effects of the bones or joints. I don't know, maybe you can ask your doctor. I do know that Tamoxifen, Femara and Arimidex work in slightly different ways to block estrogen in the body. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Questions About Femera

Posts.Content: I understand that atypical ductal hyperplasia can be a precursor to BC so your doctor has ordered one of the anti-estrogen drugs although I'm not familiar with the drug you mentioned.  I am on Femara after having stage 1 BC.  Of course, anti-estrogen drugs will only work if you are prone to having estrogen or progesterone positive fueled dysplesia or carcinoma.  Some of these drugs are not without side effects.  I personally have not suffered any ill side effects from Femara but many woman have written that they have.  Like anything else the benefits have to be wade against the risk, certainly if this drug can prevent the occurrence or delay occurrence it may be worth trying.
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia

Posts.Content: I just went back to your original posting that I read and I'm sorry you have already answered many of my questions in that posting.  I have been going back and forth to this blog and the thyroid blog and the melanoma blog as I have been diagnosed with all three and it gets confusing.  I see you not only have children but grandchildren and a husband.  I don't have any grandchildren but we do have a grand "dog".  I read your situation and all along you knew something wasn't right and no one listened.  We know our own bodies, why doesn't the medical profession listen to what we say.  They are so use to the "norm" they forget that there is always that exception.  I've been fortunate in that my breast cancer team does listen and allows me to be a partner in my care.  My thyroid team, however, associated with another hospital which has been publicised many times as a top notch facility can be a little pompous, (they know it all) and I have to keep pushing and questioning.  Forgive me for not remembering you situation.  Keep in touch!
Posts.Title: Can someone please give me some peace

Posts.Content: Unfortunately, I don't have answers on treating this, however, I had radiation therapy along with scillions of other woman and men and this has not been the bi-product in almost all cases.  My sister's fiance underwent lymph node surgery in the groin and down his leg for melanoma and also ended up with a reoccurring cellulitis, also has to deal with symptoms ongoing.  He never had radiation but extensive surgery.  I feel it most likely had to do with the extensive surgery and possible injury that triggers this problem.  Continue to investigate treatment, it is not common but others have gone through it so my guess is there may be something to help ease this process.  I'm so sorry beside the diagnosis you have to go through this.  God bless!
Posts.Title: Radiation and reoccurring Cellulitis

Posts.Content: Congratulations!  Continue to do well and enjoy life.  I will be 5 years come the end of September.  I just read an article that if you survive for 5 years cancer free, your chances are very good you 'll make it to ten.  I'm going for ten, how about you??
Posts.Title: 5 years and i,am alive. i have 43 years by romania

Posts.Content: Hi Rett! Just wanted to say how sorry I am about your dear friend.  It must have helped to have someone who understands what you are going through.  My good friend decided she was too busy or just didn't care to be involved when I was scheduled for my 7 weeks of radiation over 3 years ago.  I'm scheduled for surgery once again on August 1st, this time for thryoid cancer and I doubt I'll hear from her in the up coming weeks or months.  My daughters are young adults and pursuing their own careers etc.  It's been lonely at times going through all of this but it has made me stronger.  My husband tries to be there but he is too close and I don't want to upset him even more so I try to put on a brave face sometimes not so brave.  It is nice to have this outlet to share one's feelings.  Best wishes to you as well and God bless!
Posts.Title: Can someone please give me some peace

Posts.Content: Good for you, party for me too!!
Posts.Title: Can someone please give me some peace

Posts.Content: I agree, I lost a friend also, she was with me the day I got the diagnosis, sent me beautiful flowers after my surgery and then I went through 7 weeks of radiation therapy and never heard a peep.  Got together again and expressed some of my disappointment, then had a second primary cancer and we were out together just days before my second surgery, a neck dissection, and never got a call, a one line e-mail or a $.99 greeting card.  I know if it were reverse I could never be that way.  Don't people realize that it is bad enough that life has thrown you this curve but bailing out on a friend at a time like this, for whatever reason,  just makes the whole situation that much more.  I have found more support in strangers then from this person. It is difficult to go through some thing like this without the concern and support of the people who are suppose to care.
Posts.Title: Frustrated...

Posts.Content: Hi!  I've been on Femara for just over 3 years and have suffered no ill side effects, and the woman I work with is also taking Femara for about 4 years after being on Tamofoxin for 5 years and also has tolerated it very well.  I do read a lot on the sites however about the side effects you mention.  I understand Arimidex is very much like Femara in that way but everyone is different and different medications affect people in different ways.  I would at least try it as the worse that could happen is that you would have to stop. Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: side effects of femara

Posts.Content: If you are overreacting it is because no one is listening to you or your concerns.  Go see a breast surgeon, someone who deals with these type breast issues every day. If your mother had BC at 35 that is extremely young and the possibility of you developing BC at a young age is pretty high.  There possibly could be a mutation which is the cause when it strikes that young.  Was you mom ever tested for the BRAC l or BRAC 2 mutation?  In any event you definitely should take this seriously and pursue it until you get answers.  Not all breast lumps are malignant but with your mother's history you fall into the higher risk category.  Forget what everyone else is saying (family & friends) and make it your mission to get answers.  Your health is at stake here and your family should be understanding.  You have to put everything else on hold if necessary to take care of this problem or you jeopardize the very things you are so busy doing.  BC doesn't wait for a convenient time in out schedules.  Take care of yourself first and if family doesn't understand it is there problem.   I read an article in medical book written by a doctor who claims that patients know when something is wrong with their bodies and if you listen to them long enough they will guide you as to what needs to be done.  You are getting signals something is wrong, listen to your body and get an appointment with a Breast Surgeon ASAP.  If there is nothing to be alarmed about let a qualified doctor determine that.  Best of luck to you!!
Posts.Title: So many test, I am confussed!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi!  I cannot attribute any substantial weight gain to Femara.  I also take other medications that can contribute to weight gain.  I believe since my surgery back in late 2003 I have gained maybe 6 lbs., it fluctuates some. Don't know if it was this drug or not.  Hopes this helps.  One other mention, I joined a woman's gym, Slim & Tone, this past February and was able to work about for a good 3 months and partially for another couple weeks before being diagnosed with thyroid cancer and going for surgery etc. and had to stop.  I did notice the positive effects not so much pounds but inches and my body was reshaping to what it used to be so some type of program would address any weight fears.  Research also shows woman with breast cancer suffer less recurrence with exercise.
Posts.Title: side effects of femara

Posts.Content: One word of caution.  If you are being given the bone drugs such as Zometa either by infusion or are taking Fosamax oral medication you should NOT have any teeth pulled as you could then develop, what they have discovered to be associated, bone necrosis of the jaw.  Your dentist should be aware of this and take your medical history particulary if you are a cancer patient and on any treatment.
Posts.Title: cemo tooth

Posts.Content: I too had a complex cyst recently that showed not on my mammo but an ultrasound.  The radiologist told me the criteria is to further evaulate any complex cyst.  They usually will try to aspirate it with a needle to see if liquid comes out and it collapses.  If clear, straw colored or greenish liquid is present it is then classified as a cyst and no futher treatment is rendered.  If it does not aspirate then biopsy is indicated.  If blood is aspirated in the liquid the liquid is sent to cytology for evaluation to see if there are any cancer cells.  Mine was classified as most are as a cyst which did aspirate a clear liquid, some blood which was felt to be surface blood from piercing the skin as it collapsed.  Cytology proved this to be the case.  She should not panic at this point but follow up with their recommendation as most complex cysts turn out to be benign but again have certain questionable properties that warrant futher check.
Posts.Title: Question about Ultrasound Terminology

Posts.Content: There is a correlation between ovarian cancer and breast cancer.  I too had microcalcifications for a period and then on one of my mammos they appeared as a cluster and starting increasing in number.  The radiologist told me even though there was a cluster if he looked at each calicification individually they had defined borders so there was only a slight chance of it representing a malignancy (10%) he quoted.  Well what was going on was the cluster was forming around a small tumor (4mm) and if it weren't for that cluster it would have gone at least to my next mammo as it was not palpable, unless it became palpable before then in which case it would have been larger.  It was stage 1at that point and my lymph nodes were clear.  Your radiologist is doing you justice by making sure it doesn't represent a breast cancer.  Even it turns out to be benign or indeterminate you should be followed closely.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Microcalcifications in a cluster

Posts.Content: You're not alone in your personal medical history.  Sounds familiar to mine.  I had GYN problems from day one of my cycle with heavy periods, unbelievable clotting that after several D&C (done then) and uterine biopsies, had an ovarian cyst that ruptured that revealed endometriosis that went undiagnosed even though I mentioned to my GYN on more than one occasion that an older sister had it.  A year after that I had to have a total hysterectomy because of abnormal ultrasounds.  Turned out I had a couple conditions that could eventually turn cancerous but it was a blessing the ruptured occured so everything has been gone for over 12 years.  I was also diagnosed with melanoma and had extensive surgery on my arm with graft and removal of about 30+ lymph nodes when I was 21.  A first cousin died at age 20 from melanoma.  I have had a host of other problems including BC diagnosed almost 5 years ago and thyroid cancer a year ago.  No familar history of either and genetic testing for BRAC l & 2 and some other syndromes were negative.  I was on estrogen only, for 10 years and stopped just months prior to my diagnosis of BC after hearing about a strong link.  I feel it definitely played a role.  I was also exposed to chest x-rays over 30 years ago which were not as refined as today's, actually I had about 8 or so exposure in an 18 month period. Some I've talked to say this may have damaged the DNA at such a young age.  A genetic counselor explained that some people may have one damaged match of a cell which could be inherited.  If the second copy due to enviornment or other exposures becomes damaged as well, cancer can begin and cells may no longer have the ability to keep from reproducing abnormally.  We need healthy matching copies to produce healthy reproduction of cells.  We probaly will never know unless a mutation is revealed in the genes as to what we may be predisposed to and what other component is all that is needed to start the process.  We seek to understand somehow as if it would change things, not for us, but maybe for our children.  I sought a lumpectomy with radiation with my stage l BC and had reconstructive surgery in the form of implants a year after finishing radiation.  I also take Femara and I'm fortunate to have tolerated well thus far.  As of my last check, up, Jan. 08, all is quiet, now if I can also get my thyroid cancer in check, and my hearing and pulsatile tinnitus, oh well....just have to take one day at a time.  I just tell doctors and others that I was put together wrong.
Posts.Title: Microcalcifications in a cluster

Posts.Content: Definitely I would say there is something they want to check further.  I don't understand why they are not communicating with you.  I take it you first had a mammo, maybe your normal annual or 6 month exam.  The ultrasound would help them to clarify if something they viewed is solid or fluid filled.  An MRI, of course, is another diagnostic tool.  You have every right to be informed on whatever is concerning to them so you can also be a part of any decision process.  I had micro calcifications in 2001 they kept watching and watching and watching.  I finally spoke to my surgeon and said if they still feel a need to watch every 4 to 6 months should I just go to biopsy.  Can things change quickly.  His answer was yes, if there is an aggressive form of cancer things can change very quickly.  That's all I needed to hear.  Fortunately, it turned out to be benign, however, 2 years later I had another area of microcalcifications they were watching but this time things started to change.  There were more in number and a pattern started to emerge.  This was actually in the other breast but this time is did turn out to be BC.  Speak candidly with your doctor.  If there is something of concern ask them to describe it to you and what are the chances of it being a malignancy.  Then you can decide what you feel comfortable with.  The not knowing is the worse, it is always in the back of your mind.  Get in on the decision process so you feel comfortable. After all it is your body and your life.  Good luck!  PS (breast cancer found early has a high cure rate (stage l or 2) in the 90+% for 5 years.  Keep thatt in mind.
Posts.Title: So many test, I am confussed!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Posts.Content: I read your message and just had to write.  No, I personally am not crafty at all nor do I know someone or a group who could help.  But, I wanted to thank you as a BC 4+ year survivor for your compassion in promoting this project for the woman whom you see on a day to day basis.  I agree, the sadest of all are those woman in their 20's and 30's who either have young children or have not even reached that area of their life.  I'm so happy your area now has a breast specialist for these woman so many can be saved if their cancers are found and treated early.  God bless people like yourself who are engaging in the cause if not to cure, to help woman get through this ordeal a little easier, and to let them know someone cares and is cheering them on.
Posts.Title: Seamstres needed to make pillows for pts having axillary disection

Posts.Content: Not sure about the breast pain but I developed frozen shoulder about a year later after my radiation and surgery.  Also, they tell me to watch for signs of lymphadema which can develop in your arm at any time.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Severe breast and arm pain after 18 Years

Posts.Content: You can always seek a second opinion from another plastic surgeon on the pros and cons of each.  Silicone can only be used for BC patients as far as I know because of past controversy but it may have changed.  I personally have one implant with both saline and silicone.  This was used instead of a tissue expander as it allowed only one surgery.  The other is saline.  I am very happy with the saline implant, have not had a problem with either.  You know they have to be removed in 5 years, at least that was the last protocol I was told, so baring any intial problems with scar tissue, either should be fine.  This if the good part of the whole ordeal, getting some semblance of self back.  You should be excited about you new upcoming breasts.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Very Scared And Confused

Posts.Content: Femara is also an anti-estrogen but is in a different class and works in a different way.  A woman I work with was on Tamoxifen for 5 years and then put on Femara for another 5 for BC.
Posts.Title: Stopping the Estrogen

Posts.Content: The anti-estrogen medications such as Arimdex are published to be very effective in estrogen positive breast cancer keeping cancer at bay not only locally but elsewhere.  I have read that there is a blood test available, given to early stage breast cancer patients that can determine which patients may or may not benefit from chemo.  Studies indicate not everyone will respond to chemo despite their harsh side effects so it may or may not add any benefit.  In the case of lumpectomy, they normally do radiation to eradicate any remaining cells still left in remaining breast tissue.  I was given the option 4 years ago with my stage l to either have lumpectomy with radiation or a mastectomy.  I have read, however, that radiation after mastectomy may give some additional benefit.  I would hope that you still have your check ups with your team as there maybe residual breast tissue remaining even after mastectomy that can become cancerous so follow ups are crucial for this as well.
Posts.Title: Medication

Posts.Content: I had this used more than once on both breasts.  It is the least of your problems when checking for breast cancer.  Don't worry about this part.
Posts.Title: guide wire insertion

Posts.Content: Ditto to the other responder!
Posts.Title: need some advise

Posts.Content: I was 54 when diagnosed with BC, had a lumpectomy with additional tissue taken to obtain clear margins.  Also had a second biopsy in the same breast.  Had radiation therapy which I didn't know at the time but it shrinks the radiated breast (ongoing).  I didn't feel comfortable with my new breast and had to wear a prosthesis over it to balance and look decent in clothes.  One year after radiation I convinced my doctors that I wanted to go ahead and do reconstruction.  Since I still had some of my original breast I could have implants, took a little tweaking because the skin becomes tight after radiation but I'm happy with the results.  More importantly it really helped me to feel good about myself again and I feel I had some control over my situation.  My husband didn't want me to go through the additional surgery.  The surgery in your situation would be more extensive than with implants but definitely talk candid to your doctor and visit with a plastic surgeon who does cancer reconstruction.  As long as you are otherwise healthy it is your decision.  You may have another 20 years today as 72 is still young.  I definitely would pursue it.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Five days since mastectomy

Posts.Content: I hope you made an appointment with your doctor.  I wouldn't jump to conclusions but I know males can get BC.  I've never heard it in a male this young but young females are being diagnosed.  I guess anything is possible but I'm sure there are other reasons that it could be.  Just get him checked out.
Posts.Title: Can a teen boy have breast cancer?

Posts.Content: It could be and probably is a cyst.  However, I had a follow up MRI that showed something in my other breast, possibly a cyst.  Well I had an ultrasound guided needle aspiration and the cyst dissolved but what had shown up on the MRI was actually behind it.  My surgeon thought it to be highly suspicious for cancer but fortunately for me it turned out benign.  It is a tricky thing.  Originally I had microcalcifications that began to form a circled pattern and increase in number.  This was forming around the area of a small invasive tumor that was not yet palpable.  Thank God it did because I was diagnosed at stage l.  That was 4 years ago.
Posts.Title: what should I do

Posts.Content: Most likely a biopsy will be indicated.  There are several types so it will be up to your doctor.  For every 10 women that go in for biopsy, 8 will be negative so satistics are in your favor.  Of course, if there is a high familial incidence of BC than that number can go up.  Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: Uncertain

Posts.Content: I too had BC 4 years ago and diagnosed with thyroid cancer this past June.  I asked my endocrinologist about how long I had the thyroid cancer, as I am stage 3, and he said about 3 to 4 yrs. Interesting!  I have met several women on the thyroid site and this site that have been diagnosed with thyroid then BC or BC then thyroid.  I'm beginning to believe there may be a connection in our cases.  I do not have any history of either BC or thyroid cancer.  My mother does take meds for a slightly sluggish thyroid but she had weight problems for many years.  It wouldn't hurt to have a fine needle aspiration done.  What is your age?  Most thyroid cancer is the common papillary version but there are variants such as what I have that is more aggressive.  I for one wish they had found my small nodule earlier before it broke through a capsule and entered a lymph node.  It is your health.  If you are going to feel uncomfortable not knowing relay this to you doctor.  I'm in my 50's by the way.
Posts.Title: Breast cancer and now a tumor on my Thyroid

Posts.Content: On Oct 29, 2009 1:26 AM atomicjoy wrote: On Oct 28, 2009 7:31 PM Leemg wrote: Donna, I was reading the response from atomicjoy and at first I had to look to see who wrote it.  My story begins the same, microcalcifications with a 10% chance of malignancy and it was.  Thyroid nodules which turned out to be stage 3 thyroid cancer.  But today I'm doing well because I was diagnosed and treated.  I would agree that I would push for a biopsy even if I had to find another doctor to do so.  You are probably making yourself sick worrying and this doesn't do anyone any good.  Talk to your doctor and tell him you can't sleep at nights and if he or she doesn't move forward, find another doctor.  If all turns out to be okay that you can relax for now.  Keep us informed. Leemg, I post on the thyroid cancer thread as well as this one.  In fact, there are a couple of us on the thyroid thread that have had both breast and thyroid cancer.  I was diagnosed in March 06 with Stage 1 BC and was diagnosed in March 09 with Stage 3 thyroid cancer with a Tall cell variant (a more aggressive form).  My thyroid cancer was already there when I was diagnosed with breast cancer but went undetected because I was too passive and put too much trust in my doctors at the time.  It is really up to each and every one of us to be proactive in our own healthcare.  After all, you know your own body best and you know when something is wrong despite of what a doctor may tell you to ignore. Atomicjoy Atomicjoy, I can't believe that we are like a carbon copy of one another.  I too was diagnosed with stage 1 BC but in September of 2003, and stage 3 thyroid cancer (also tall cell, more aggressive variant) in August 2007,  after awhile it all goes together.  I was not aware of any problem with my thyroid so that was also a total surprise.  I'm assuming it had spread to some lymph nodes to be classified as stage 3 (thyroid cancer)?  I had a left neck dissection in February of 2008.  So far it looks stable, although my thyroglobulin is measureable it is still under 2.  Breast cancer is stable as well although I've had two biopsies since.  How are you doing?  My parotid glands were damaged, not right away, but after my year scan so I deal with dry mouth.  (I lost one parathyroid gland with surgery).  I also have problems keeping my calcium levels within normal limits and had a low D which has been corrected.  Love to hear how things have gone for you.
Posts.Title: I am very worried Two Mammo`s Dense breasts lump

Posts.Content: Wow!  I thought the PET was the best screening technique out there but maybe not.  I do know regarding those other areas that are still lighting on the PET is a good indicator that treatment is working.  I know how you must feel getting the bad news overturned, believe me, but since your health is on the line here maybe a 3rd opinion of all the CD's of your films at another reliable facility would either fall with one or the other.  I think I would feel better with two similar opinions than two that are at odds.  Yes, it is amazing the different takes you can get.  If they are just looking at the takes done with films it may be missing important info so it is best to allow them to see the entire CD.  That is what I've learned.  Also, just after being diagnosed with bc 5 years ago I was sent for a bone scan and the facility that performed the scan aware I had bc diagnosed an area around my spine as mets, 6 weeks later after having other doctors go over my test results, indicated that it was a degenerative process and I guess they were right as it has been 5 years.  I've also have had two doctors look at an enhancement within my inner ear that indicate it is a benign growth and other that say that can't be confirmed with the testing I had and need more safisticated testing.  And, we are talking about the best in their field.  I wish you the best of luck and hope and pray that the better report holds.  God Bless!
Posts.Title: conflicting petct and new ct scan reports?

Posts.Content: I think it is unusual that a doctor would not do perhaps CT scans or a PET scan to see if it had spread to bone or any organs such as the liver or brain which are areas of spread for breast cancer.  It can be in a few lymph nodes under the arm and still be considered stage 11 which is treatable.  Did she have a sentinel node biopsy or axillary node dissection??  or have they found significant lumps in this area, possibly in the breast as well?  This certainly would indicate a more wide spread disease.  Is she experiencing any symptoms, pain for example.  Chemotherapy can be offered in this case not as a cure but to slow down the process.  Also, radiation can be used for bone pain.  It is unusual to diagnosis a patient in a weeks time and send her off and do nothing.  Ask to see her pathology report. How old is your mother?  Do you live nearby?  I would make an appointment with her doctor and go along with her.
Posts.Title: I want to verify cancer diagnosis

Posts.Content: I'm disappointed that your radiation oncologist did not give you something when it became apparent it was going to be a problem.  I had a female radiologist oncologist and I also knew I had sensitive skin so I discussed this with her prior to radiation.  There is a cream Biafine Radiation cream available by prescription.  I put this on immediately before starting treatment.  You have to wash it off before treatment but than it can be reapplied and work overnight and washed off in the shower before heading off to treatment.  I had a pink breast for several months but never red and never became a real problem.  The doctors commented on how well my skin tolerated the radiation and again I have very fair sensitive skin so I defiinitely attribute it to the cream.  Using Aquaphor healing ointment is a good choice at this point and ice compresses may help 2 to 3x daily for 10 to 15 minutes.  I know this because I also work for a dermatologist and listen to the recommendations for his patients.  I wish doctors' would be considerate of their patient's overall well being.  You can't treat the condition without treating the patient as a whole.  Hope it heals quickly for you.  Sorry, you didn't have to go through this severe reaction.
Posts.Title: Severe burn after radiation...

Posts.Content: You sound like your scared to death!  I understand you feelings.  I too had an area of concern that was being followed and followed and followed.  One day sitting in the office for a follow up mammo again, we all got to talking which is strange because most of the time no one says a word.  In the conversation a women ask me what I was there for and I told her they had been following.....  She said, "what are you waiting for?"  "if they aren't sure by now push to have it biopsied.  She proceeded to tell me about a friend who was a nurse and had an area and one of her colleage doctors told her to recheck in 6 months.  Ended up she had an aggressive form and in 6 months it had moved to her bones etc.  This scared the grap out of me so I had a good long talk with my surgeon.  We went ahead and had it removed and fortunately it turned out to be benign so I was able to again sleep at nights.  Here's a twist 2 years later I did develop BC in the other breast.  There is no reason you have to second guess this, in all likelihood it is benign but once you know you can take a deep breath and get back to your life.  Good luck.  Don't be afraid to tell your surgeon that the unknown is wearing you down and you have concerns because of family history.  If you are seeing the right doctor he will understand and proceed.
Posts.Title: I am very worried Two Mammo`s Dense breasts lump

Posts.Content: Donna, I was reading the response from atomicjoy and at first I had to look to see who wrote it.  My story begins the same, microcalcifications with a 10% chance of malignancy and it was.  Thyroid nodules which turned out to be stage 3 thyroid cancer.  But today I'm doing well because I was diagnosed and treated.  I would agree that I would push for a biopsy even if I had to find another doctor to do so.  You are probably making yourself sick worrying and this doesn't do anyone any good.  Talk to your doctor and tell him you can't sleep at nights and if he or she doesn't move forward, find another doctor.  If all turns out to be okay that you can relax for now.  Keep us informed.
Posts.Title: I am very worried Two Mammo`s Dense breasts lump

Posts.Content: You must have breast cancer??  Breast cancer in the ducts is the most common form.  I assume you had a biopsy to diagnose this??  Have they suggested as to what your next step will be?  Once the tumor is removed there will be staging which is very important.  It is usual for them to remove nodes under the arm as well.  Today, many use a sentinel node biopsy.  My doctor did the old fashion lymph node dissection, 11 nodes in all.  All were negative.  Until you get staged it will be difficult, as from experience, your mind just runs amuck, imagining the worse.  It is a lonely time as well.  I know I felt that the rest of the world was spinning like a merry go round that I was no longer a part of but let me tell you that you will regain your life again.  It may be different but there will again be normalcy.  Don't be afraid to get a second opinion if needed.  There are some varying opinions on the aggressiveness of treatment.  I was diagnosed almost five years ago at age 54.  I had a lumpectomy followed by 7 weeks of radiation, no chemo.  It depends on the stage and your age.  In my case I had stage 1 and they felt chemo would be an overkill at that point. They do have anti-estrogen drugs if the tumor is estrogen/progesterin positve as most are, but some also or have a HER2 positive component which does not respond to these drugs but I believe they have a specific treatment for these patients as well.  I have been on Femara over 4 years and have tolerated it well.  I would suggest that you understand as much about your situation as possible.  This gave me some control over my situation as I was a part of the decision making process.  I would suggest that you feel comfortable with you team of doctors.  My doctors are great.  They know me as a person not just another patient.  This helped.  You sound as though you have a wonderful family and support system.  Feel free to write and ask questions.  Someone here most likely will be able to help or guide you.  May God bless!
Posts.Title: alone

Posts.Content: Hi!  Sometimes if you still have your ovaries they will remove them.  Your body still produces estrogen even without ovaries.  Tamoxifen and other replacement therapy are actually anti-estrogen drugs.  There are different classes that work in different ways to block estrogen so you would be wise to try them if your doctor suggests.  Tamoxifen is the gold standard, not the most effective these days as other such as Femara which I'm taking show to be more effective.  But many women cannot tolerate aromitase drugs such as Femara.  Tamoxifen probably is least likely to cause side effects.  DO NOT confuse estrogen hormone replacement therapy such as Premarin (which is an estrogen producing drug) with hormone therapy such as Tamoxifen.  You are right to stay away from estrogen producing anything if your BC was hormone positive.  Again, there are estrogen producing drugs such as Premarin that you probably want to avoid like the plaque but ANTI-estrogen drugs play a crucial role in keeping estrogen postive BC at bay.
Posts.Title: Stopping the Estrogen

Posts.Content: I can't believe in this day and age with everything out there about breast cancer your doctors didn't take your symptoms more seriously.  I don't even know you but I know if you have a mom and sister with BC you are at high risk at developing this disease.  A mammo isn't always the answer.  You may have an infection of some kind in the breast but there are different types of BC and everyone is unique to some degree.  At the very least you should have had follow up testing and follow up by a breast surgeon.  The lesions in your brain may very well be benign.  I have some benign lesions that have nothing to do with my BC.  Besides addressing the breast, however, you propably should be having some CT, MRI or bone scans to see if there are other lesions present.  Don't jump to conclusions about the brain lesions but do see someone who takes your symptoms seriously.  At the very least you need a thorough exam with follow up testing.  Best of luck!
Posts.Title: Info told mets to the brain

Posts.Content: One other comment, Neosporin is a good topical antibiotic ointment but some people are allergic to it such as myself.  If you have increased redness or weeping you may be having an allergic reaction so keep this in mind othewise as I said it is a good topical antibiotic.  If you are having an allergic reaction though, Bactroban is another alternative but you need a prescription for this.
Posts.Title: Severe burn after radiation...

Posts.Content: I'm not sure what it is that your daughter is taking.  She was extremely young to have to deal with BC.  I believe you said she had estrogen positive BC which means that if she still has her ovaries she is probably taking something to suppress the estrogen in her body.  I take it that she is not currently on chemo??  If they are suppressing the estrogen then this would cause symptoms of menapause even in a 28 year old.  This would be the reason for the hot flashes and possibly the depression but being diagnosed with BC at such a young age and feeling that she is alone could also be the cause of her depression.  Yes, as most woman are older at the time of their BC diagnosis it is not always the case.  When I was going through radiation therapy there was a 22 year old who had to have a mastectomy.  She just needs to contact the cancer support group or large hospital and ask about one specific to young women.  She should continue seeing her doctor's who would monitor her care and follow up tests.  I'm sorry she doesn't have health insurance but again I would contact the American Cancer Society or similar organization and see what can be done to insure she gets the proper care and medications for the treatment and follow up of her BC to insure she remains cancer free.  Best of luck to you and her!
Posts.Title: hormone treatment

Posts.Content: I live in NJ but I believe it was a federal ruling that mandates insurance companies to pay not only for mastectomies due to cancer but reconstruction surgery not only of the affected breast but the other breast to balance.  I actually had lost a lot of breast tissue due to two biopsies, a lumpectomy and an infection and underwent reconstruction by the way of implants in both breasts.  So, the answer is yes.  I went to a plastic surgeon affiliated with the hospital where I had the surgery.   I've been very happy with the results. I also had radiation to the affected breasts before surgery.
Posts.Title: breasts lift?

Posts.Content: I would definitely make an appointment with a breast surgeon ASAP.  There are different types of BC.  There is inflammatory breast cancer as well.  It may be nothing to worry about but with your strong history, I definitely would pursue it.  Our guts are pretty reliable in this respect.  Let us know how things progress.
Posts.Title: After 36 years, I'm worried again

Posts.Content: Tamoxifen as well as other anti-estrogen therapies have proven to help prevent recurrence of BC.  Tamoxifen has been on the market a long time and was the gold standard until other drugs such as Femara and Arimidex came on the market for postmenapausal women.  They work in different ways.  They normally only keep you on Tamoxifen for 5 years and it does not seem to work after that amount of time but you may be able to be switched to other medications that do the same thing or work in another way. It is not a cure though as some women may sustain a recurrence while on the medication but it reduces that.  As for symptoms it all depends on the person.  Some do not experience any ill side effects and others do.  Best of luck!
Posts.Title: hormon therapy for breastcancer
