Posts.Content: I had an old fashion lymph node dissection rather than sentinel 5 years ago, 11 nodes total (all negative TG) and I recovered from surgery very well, did my arm exercises, can hardly notice any scar and no after effects at all.  I also had 30+ lymph nodes removed from the opposite axillary area over 30 years ago for melanoma surgery, and I had about 9 lymph nodes removed from my left neck and thyoid area for thyroid cancer.  Of course, they tell me, which I didn't know for about 30 years, that they should not use a blood pressure cup, needles etc. from the arm with lymph node removal.  For me, that is both sides.  I've been told by an ER doctor that they should only be using my legs for this because of lymphedema developing which can occur at any time.  Thus far I have not had a problem with this either.  I wouldn't be overly concerned about having addditional nodes removed.
Posts.Title: Lymph Dissection

Posts.Content: I don't undestand what happened here.  What did they see originally to cause you to have a lumpectomy in the first place?  I had microcalcifications which turned out to be BC with a .3 mm break through tumor which could not be palpated.  When doing the lumpectomy my surgeon sent the specimen to pathology with a needle in it to insure all the area had been removed.  They also checked for clear margins around the area before the surgery was considered successful.  If this punctate calcification which would have been definitely suspicious was there it should have been removed at the time of your surgery again with clear margins.  This should have been done before radiation therapy.  I would try to get a clarification as to what happened???  Make sure it is dealt with.  You don't want to have gone through surgery and radiation and not have them address the problem .  You don't want them to leave any evidence of cancer or a precancer in place.  Good luck!!
Posts.Title: calcification

Posts.Content: It is always worisome when someone loses 10 lbs. or more particulary if your are a cancer patient.  I would get in touch with your doctor's to have a check up. Best wishes!
Posts.Title: symptoms of liver mets

Posts.Content: I was on Premarin for ten years and stopped when the news came out regarding it's adverse effects particulary BC.  I was diagnosed 2 months after I stopped with invasive stage 1 BC.  There are class action suits currently going on if you took the combination estrogen and progesterin because the first reports came out linking that combination but initial reports did not find any evidence for estrogen alone.  Since that time I believe they have made the connection but no attorneys that I'm aware of are ready to take just Premarin patients. I had contacted two lawyers who were publishing on the web but turned me down because of just being on Premarin alone.  I myself am waiting for the first suit to come along.
Posts.Title: Law suit against makers of Premarin

Posts.Content: I can relate.  If you were diagnosed with either stage l or 11 BC, estrogen positive & Her neg, then lumpectomy with radiation has proven to be just as effective as mastectomy.  This was my choice 4 years ago and I also have small breasts.  I was concerned about the amount of tissue I lost from the affected breast as I needed two biopsies, one which developed and infection and then the lumpectomy to obtain clear margins.  If they can not obtain clear margins then you would have to resort to mastectomy anyway.  One word of caution as you mention you weren't doing reconstruction.  The radiation continues to shrink the treated breast as my surgeon said, "it is the gift that keeps on giving".  This was concerning for me as I had to wear a prosthesis over the remaining breast to balance.  Once being radiated you can opt for reconstruction but would have to wait about a year before doing so.  I had implants put in a year after completion of my radiation.  The scar which went across most of the middle of my breast was tight so I had a second procedure to soften the scar and the implant fell into a normal placing.  I am very satisfied with the final result today.  Of course, implants have to be replaced in about 5 years so this is something else to consider.  If you do opt. for a mastectomy, they can do reconstruction immediately or at a later time as well if you change your mind down the road.  As you can see this is a personal decision.  One other word of caution, a friend of a woman I work with opt for a mastectomy after diagnosed with in-situ and they couldn't obtain clear margins but didn't understand the extent of her procedure.  She lost muscle and her scar came above the scoop line in a normal top one would wear and she lost so much tissue under her arm that left a hole that needed a flap and she can't wear sleeveless tops either because she feels so self conscious.  This has caused her some depression as she was not aware of the extent of her mastectomy so make sure you have this understanding before making your choice.  Hope this helps!!
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy vs. Mastectomy

Posts.Content: Natasha,  You have to tell an adult if you can't go to your mom, an aunt or whoever you feel comfortable.  You need to see a doctor ASAP.  Just tell them you need to see a doctor and ask if they can make you an appointment.  Once you get to a doctor they will guide you as to what needs to be done.  Please don't let your fear stop you another day.
Posts.Title: im scared that i might have cancer

Posts.Content: You indicated you are aware of lawsuits for estrogen alone therapy.  I would like to know about that.  I've been waiting for that to happen.  On estrogen therapy (Premarin) ten years, stopped and one month later diagnosed with BC, hormone receptor positive.  Thanks!
Posts.Title: I took Estrogene alone..lawsuit or not?

Posts.Content: I will, thanks for responding!  By the way I live in NJ.
Posts.Title: I took Estrogene alone..lawsuit or not?

Posts.Content: Arnold, I am so sorry for your loss.  Your sister was so lucky to have someone who loved her so dearly.
Posts.Title: My Dearest Sister Passed away

Posts.Content: I can't address all your questions. As far as information on ovarian cancer I'm sure there are others with your type of cancer. I don't know specific sites as I'm a breast cancer patient and usually hit those sites. Your doctors should be candid about your treatment options available for your stage and type of cancer. Many doctors who are affilated with larger hospital systems or care centers have people on board such as cancer counselors, nutrionist, social workers etc. If you see a local doctor, most counties have programs, look in the phone book or call your county office. As far as disability, you didn't say what state you are from, NJ has state short term disability as well as long term disability if needed. Check with your state. How long it takes to get back into the main stream depends on your treatment and stage. Surgery generally takes about 6 weeks to recover. Radiation if considered can cause fatigue and some other symptoms pending on the area of body radiated. Your radiation oncologist would be able to advise you on this. You probably will also have a medical oncologist and they plan and treat with any oral medications or chemotherapy that may be necessay, here again, ask questions. Your doctors should be willing to discuss any and all you questions andif they do not, find other doctors who will work with you to provide the best treatment plan for your specific case. There is information out there, take a deep breath and start making phone calls etc. The internet is a good source of finding others in your situation. I wish you the best,you're not alone. Hope this brings some comfort.
Posts.Title: Help Please, Any Info is Appreciated

Posts.Content: I loved your last paragraph Jodie.  Direct this to Him and I'm sure He will do just that!  Your life is and has always been beneficial.
Posts.Title: medistinal lymph nodes still show active br. ca.

Posts.Content: Have they checked your ferritin levels (iron).  I had a low red blood count which lead to iron deficient anemia.  To confirm this they specifiically have to check the ferritin.  Many of the symptoms you mentioned I experienced.  I never realized it until my medical oncologist called me.  I had to go on and actually I'm currently on iron therapy.
Posts.Title: CBC readings...red blood cells a little low?

Posts.Content: I believe several of us are waiting for action against the makers of Premarin.  I too was on Premarin for ten years, off 2 months after hearing news to it's adverse effects regarding BC, and then diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma with estrogen/progesterin positive, HER neg.  No familiar history of BC and also tested for mutations and neg.  I'm also convinced it played a role, after all, we were feeding our bodies estrogen and now I'm taking an anti-estrogen as therapy.  There is evidence out there but I guess not enough to begin a law suit but it should be coming I would hope.  I'm in NJ.  Not only did it probably play a role but we were prescribed it to protect our hearts and help ease with menapause, in my case after having a hysterectomy, and to protect our bones, only later to find out that it didn't do any of these good things.  I developed osteoporosis while taking Premarin so all it did for me was set the stage for my BC I believe.  Let me know if you hear anything in this regard.
Posts.Title: Premarin Law Suit Only?

Posts.Content: Hi Hope!  What a beautiful name.  It sounds as though you have a very competent medical team and the main thing is that You feel comfortable  with them.  It sounds like they are covering all the bases up to this point.   I'm glad you went ahead and had genetic testing.  This will benefit not only you but your two daughters.  I can't say what is right for you as far as a bilateral mastectomy but I do know that many BRAC l and BRAC 2 patients have opted for a bilateral because of the high incidence of BC.  But again this is something you have to discuss with your doctors to see what the benefit would be.  I've also read an article featured on women who have had mastectomies and reconstruction and how satisfied the majority were in their decision.  I had the option of either a lumpectomy with radiation or a lateral mastectomy with stage 1BC, and I opted for the lumpectomy but later had to have reconstruction surgery.  So again, if you have an option it is a very personal choice.  Peace of mind is worth a lot though.  I know the waiting is so difficult.  I found it to be the worst part.  You have too much time to think of all the bad things that can happen, yet not knowing and your life seems to go on hold, finding yourself just going through the motions and hoping and praying for the best outcome.  Too many of us have been there.  Wait until all the tests are in before jumping to any conclusions or making any decision.  Make sure you have someone with you for doctor appointments.  I know how you feel about having cancer in your body and just wanting it out but a few weeks probably won't change anything and you have to live with your decision so you don't want it to be a rash one.  Make it on a well thought out decision.   Again, Hope I feel for you.  Hang in there girl.  Many of us are routing for you to have the best possible outcome.
Posts.Title: First Stage

Posts.Content: Hi!  I was on Premarin for ten years and stopped two months shy of developing BC after hearing the link between estrogen and BC.  Unfortunately, the only lawsuits are for women who took both the estrogen and progesterone combination as the original study showed that link but not necessarily estrogen alone.  I'm from NJ.  Should you hear about any lawsuit for estrogen alone patients, I would like to hear about it but thus far I haven't found anyone to help us.  A suggestion, you should list your heading under Premarin and BC link or Premarin and lawsuits as one wouldn't know under your current heading that you are looking for anyone aware of attorneys taking cases for Premarin patients.
Posts.Title: cancer diagnsos

Posts.Content: My thoughts are with you Jodie.  That Avemar sounds pretty hopeful!  I have also read several pieces of info on the benefits of  Vit. C intravenous therapy and alternative treatments used to cleanse the body of toxins.  A woman my husband works for sent me an issue of someone with stage 4 who found these supplements and diet 5 years ago and has since had about 300+ woman working with her.  Unfortunately, I cannot find the article for any more specifics but maybe you can look into this in your area.  I do know a woman I work with has a sister who is over 14 years with stage 4 BC.  When she was diagnosed she went to a clinic up in NY and went cold turkey and began a specific diet, meditation etc.  I don't think she is as strict as she once was in following this regimen but is still living a normal life.  I received a Healing Prayer Book in the mail and this is what is says:  The practice of medicine remains, at best, an inexact science.  There are cases where drs. were wrong or where sheer determination conquered an illness.  There are "miracles". (excerpts) Because of these things, we can and must always keep alive the hope that health problems can improve.  Our bodies are wonderful creations with untold powers for healing and regenerating.  Even if a condition is irreversible, often it is through our health problems that we can find the pathway to developing our talents in new and different ways.  God gave us the gift of life and has tremendous power to guide, direct and assist this healing process.  Through prayer, we bring our health needs to the Lord, asking for His help and healing and accepting His answer as His will for us.  May God give you his guidance to live out His will.  I will pray for you as well.
Posts.Title: medistinal lymph nodes still show active br. ca.

Posts.Content: First I am so sorry you are going through this.  I have a daughter 32 and I would be devastated if she had to go through this at such a young age.  Next I want to say to seek the best breast cancer facility and team of doctors you can.  I went across the river to a big city hospital because the hospitals here were still up and coming.  Never be afraid to seek a second or even third opinion.  If there are several tumors within the breast they most likely will do a mastectomy.  You should have an MRI of the other breast, it is not unusual to have it occurring in both breasts.  Do to your age etc. they will probably suggest chemotherapy.  I personally did not need chemo at my onset but I'm postmenapausal.  This also makes a difference.  After surgery they will stage your BC and should talk about any options for treatment if any.  Do you have a family history of BC, many times young woman do and carry a mutation BRAC l or BRAC 2.  You need to educate yourself.  While going through radiation my hospital had BC sessions they were conducting and I attended them.  There are organizations out there for young woman with BC, ask your doctor or call the cancer community in your area, they should be able to refer you, or many times your hospitals have them.  I know, you must feel like you just had a train wreck, know the feeling.  Do you have anyone around you, a husband, boyfriend, mother, sister or close friend.  You definitely need the support of someone close to you.  I will keep you in my thoughts and prayers.  God Bless!
Posts.Title: First Stage

Posts.Content: To answer your question, Most Definitely!  It will either determine there is no problem or there is a problem, in which case must be addressed ASAP!
Posts.Title: LCIS

Posts.Content: I had to write after reading your message to Judy. I too had a lumpectomy? (l/3 breast tissue)with radiation. My surgeon informed me AFTER THE FACT that there would be shrinkage. I had to wear a prosthesis against the remaining breast tissue for balance. My doctors tried to sway me away from reconstructive surgery due to the questionable outcome on a radiated breast but I was persistent. I faired well with my skin actually. Having sensitive skin from the onset I was given a radiation cream that kept any redness or burning to a minimum. After one year (I agreed to wait one year) I had implants although due to the large scar area across my breast the implant did not fall properly behind the scar. I had an implant that also served as an expander. But after a doctor ruptured the implant in the opposite breast trying to perform a core biopsy I headed back to surgery. My cosmetic surgeon softened the original lumpectomy scar allowing the implant to assume a more natural position. Of course, I understand radiation is the gift that keeps on giving so I'm hoping the implant keeps it from rising to my scapula. You made me laugh. Good luck to you.
Posts.Title: Diep Flap

Posts.Content: Yes, I know Femara which I believe is in the same class can deplete from bone.  It is interesting that your bone density came out well.  Is the surgeon sure it wasn't arthritis in the lumbar spine?  In any event I haven't heard any adverse affect in the heart such as blockages.  Has their been any study to support this?  One thing I do want to mention, do you also take Vit. D with your calcium??  You need D to absorb the calcium.  It is possible that without the Fosamax and calcium supplement the osteo would have been much worse.  Hope you continue to do well otherwise.
Posts.Title: Arimidex withdrawal symptoms

Posts.Content: Jodie, Good luck & thank you for your well wishes!
Posts.Title: CBC readings...red blood cells a little low?

Posts.Content: Hi Josh!  Sounds as though your holding up well.  Breast cancer is usually found in the milk ducts or lobes.  Sometimes it is in the fat tissue.  Liquid usually means of a cystic nature particularly if it is clear but you mentioned small pieces of tumor, not sure what that could be.  Possibly an infection of some kind, hopefully, it is a good sign.  Let us know how things turn out.  We have all been praying for her and you and your baby girl.
Posts.Title: Scared for my Wife

Posts.Content: It depends on so many factors, your age, your familiar history, if it was estrogen/progesterin positive or negative, if it was HER 2 positive.  The actually staging after they look at the cells in pathology to see how closely they resemble a normal cell etc.  If there were no positive lymph nodes you chances would be greater that you may not need chemo but if you are younger, they do give chemo because you are not a candidate for some of the oral anti-estrogen medications on the market.  Of course, the PET will show if there is any spread.  You will just have to wait and see what the findings reveal.  I know, believe me I know, this is the hardest part, the waiting.  After diagnosed with stage l and being assured that I had a 90 some percent chance of cure I had a bone scan and to my horror it showed uptake in the rib.  Talking with my surgeon he went quiet.  A follow up bone scan revealed a second lesion and we were talking possibly 2 years (survival) with my oncologist, when he said something just wasn't right.  Further evaluation of my tests by an oncologist radiation specialist after now 6 weeks felt it probably was not related to the BC.  My doctors were afraid to do any more testing unless I actually had symptoms because something unusual always presented.  That was 3 years ago and all is well.  So think positive if you can.  Let us know how things turn out.  God bless and give you patience through all this. I found Ambien to be my friend for awhile.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy and PET...Now what??

Posts.Content: I believe Arimidx and Femara work the same way. I take Femara and have been on that just over 5 years.  My oncologist suggested stopping as research showed Tamoxifen can only be taken for 5 years but the research is still out on this class of drugs and I had showed him a whole host of reasons to continue taking it for now.  I do know that this class of drug has a tendency to deplete some bone where as Tamoxifen does not.  I actually developed osteo before having BC and starting this medication, so it is hard to say whether you would have developed this regardless.  I have been on a calcium supplement and Vit. D regimen and get Zometa infusion (similar to Fosamax but infustion form) since starting Femara.  I still have osteo but it has not become worse and may even improved somewhat.  Age and genes, lack of excercise etc. are better predectors of both the diseases you mention.  Did your doctor have you on any bone medication such as Foxamax or calc. supplements while you were taking Arimidex?
Posts.Title: Arimidex withdrawal symptoms

Posts.Content: I agree with the other responses that you have to find an oncologist that your are comfortable with.  As far as the estrogen, Tamoxifen works to block the amount of estrogen that could stimulate a new cancer.  They have found, however, that Arimidex and Femara both of which work in a similar way but different from Tamoxifen work better in deterring the recurrernce of BC.  That is why you doctor was so insistent but you are right with those drugs can come a problem with bone loss.  However, there are drugs like Fosamax and the taking of calcium and Vit. D that can counter those side effects.  But Tamoxifen is still a good product.  They normally do not monitor the amounts of estrogen circulating in your body as they are doing all they can by prescribing the above drugs to deal with that.  There are cancer markers, however, that have come about since I was diagnosed 4 years ago.  I don't know the name of the specific marker but some doctors may not feel comfortable with relying on these as yet.  If you have had cancer in one breast, we are at an increased risk of having it in the other so vigilance and having your mammos are still extremely important, self exams and reporting any changes to your doctor right away. Also, you should be followed at least yearly if not more to look for clinical sings of a recurrence such as a lump or swollen lymph nodes any where.  Excercise has been proven to play an important role as well as diet.  So these are some of the things we can do day to day.  But most importantly is to find someone you trust in dealing with your health that you feel comfortable with.  I was recently diagnosed with thyroid cancer and my breast medical and surgical team were able to help me by getting and supplying medical info that helped me in my treatment plan with that.  You need to find a team that sees you as a person.  I've been fortunate to have that.
Posts.Title: recurrence

Posts.Content: I also wanted to express how sorry I am for the loss of your mother and grandmother to BC.  One day, hopefully, it will no longer have to be that way.  Take care!
Posts.Title: breast mri

Posts.Content: Considering your family history and your concerns over this I would ask for a definitive diagnosis.  I had what was classified as an "inderminate" area several years ago and every 6 months they would recheck and it was still "inderminate", 18 months had gone by, then while sitting in the office waiting to get a follow up mammo the ladies starting talking, one asked me about my situation and I told her.  She kid of yelled at and said "what was I waiting for, if they don't know for certain by now".  She continued to tell me a friend of hers that was a nurse who had a questionable area and a colleague (doctor) said just to have it rechecked in 6 months.  Well six months later she found out not only was it malignant but it was aggressive and had already spread to her liver and bones.  Well that is all I needed to hear and I called my surgeon and we agreed to have it biopsied.  It turned out to be benign in my case but 2 years later I was diagnosed with stage 1 in the opposite breasts.  There is no reason to lose sleep just tell them you want to know for certain if for no other reason to put your mind at ease.
Posts.Title: breast mri

Posts.Content: Hi Hope!  To be honest I do not know much about the different surgical techniques since I had a lumpectomy but at one point a nurse was talking to me a little about the tram, that her mother had that and was very pleased and if I had to consider mastectomy this would be a good choice but I really don't have any specifics.  You are not at all alone.  I know when you life is consumed with waiting for tests and their results, seeing doctors and going to hospitals and spending time gathering as much info as possible it becomes your world and there is a feeling of isolation.  Like there is a world going on around you but you feel you are not a part of it.  This will eventually change after you get through the initial treatment.  Unfortunately, the initial phase takes some time and when you are consumed by all this, hours turn into days and days into weeks etc. It seems as though life will never be normal again but eventually it will, it may be different or a new normal.  I am doing fine.  I had my 4 year mammo and ultrasound last January and everything is A okay.  I see my doctors about every 4 months or so.  Actually I'm due to see my medical oncologist this Friday.  I also get Zometa infusions every 6 months now to help with bone loss from the Femara.  I have osteoporosis and this helps to keep things stable.  I'm currently going through a process to get ready for a whole body scan for my thyroid cancer.  My blood levels were a little higher than they would like so this is all happening this week.  Had an ultrasound of my neck and everything looked good.  Go back to my endocrinologist mid August to go over the results.  Hopefully, everything will be okay and I can get another break from all this.  Thanks you for asking.
Posts.Title: First Stage

Posts.Content: You have a lot of questions, know the feeling.  She is so fortunate to have someone like yourself who cares so much.  I'll try to address what I can.  Yes, they usually either do a sentinel node biopsy or a resecction (the older method) while doing a lumpectomy or mastectomy to see how many if any lymph nodes were involved.  Pending on the size of the breast tumor, location, (ductal or lobular) it's grade, whether it is estrogen/progesterin or HER-2 positive they set the course of treatment.  Also, if she is premenapausal this will come into play.  The fact that they started her on Tamoxifen tells me that it was either estrogen and/or progesterin postive which means it will most likely respond to the anti-estrogen drug, Tamoxifen.  The fact that they choose Tamoxifen rather than the other newer class of drugs such as Femara or Arimidex tells me she is probably premenapausal.  If this is the case she probably will be a candidate for some sort of chemo or radiation or both.  If they do a mastectomy sometimes you can avoid radiation but if you have a lumpectomy, radiation is the norm.  The side effects from Tamoxifen are the least problematic from what I have read and it is effective, of course, everyone responds differently to medication.  This is a rough time for your sister in law.  Trying to get a grasp on what is going on and trying to educate yourself so you are informed enough to make decisions if given options while still trying to cope with the diagnosis is very difficult.  Allow her some time to just get a grasp on all this.  It would help if she would like, that you go along with her on her doctor appointments or at least make sure someone accompanies her.  It is so difficult to try to comprehend everything and all the medical terminology and the other person could help take this info in for her if she has questions later.  Don't panic at this point.  Stage l and 2 BC patients like myself can do very well.  It has been over 4 years for me and belive it or not life does return to normalcy, sometimes it is a new normal.  I know when I was first diagnosed and going to doctors and hospitals I felt removed from the everyday world going on outside and felt it may never be normal again but it does get better.  The important thing now is that she get the best care and most aggressive treatment she needs up front. I wish her and you the best!
Posts.Title: Sister in Law

Posts.Content: I'm not sure what site you were at but many breast cancer patient's are on Zometa or other type medications.  Many woman who have osteoporosis or osteopenia take Fosomax, Actonel etc. so you can post your experience on this site as well.  I for one take Zometa infusions and are aware of necrosis of the jaw as a result of phoso.(sp?).  I've been told that woman who take phoso. should never have a tooth pulled to expose the bone.  I actually have gone to the doctor who first wrote the article on this subject.  I would love to hear your experience in this regard.
Posts.Title: ONJ

Posts.Content: Rest in peace Kelly and continue to watch over your sister!
Posts.Title: My wonderful sister

Posts.Content: I am so sorry to hear what you both are going through.  I'll pray to God for her that everything is okay but when I was dealing with the prospect that I could have breast cancer it was important to me to hear my husband say that it would be okay even if it turned out to cancer.  That he would still love me and it would not change the way he viewed me and most of all that we would go through it together.  To know he would be my #1 support and believe together we could get through it helped tremendously.  Let her knew you love and will support her no matter what.  I'll keep you both in my prayers.
Posts.Title: Scared for my Wife

Posts.Content: You're making a big mistake as far as foregoing mammograms. They do save lives.  One saved mine and I had micro calcifications.  I had them discovered a couple years prior but on this occasion (and it was a normal yearly) the calicifications were becoming more in number and starting to form a pattern.  Turns out they were encircling a small tumor that had broke out of the duct.  I was lucky as it was still stage 1 with no mets to the lymph nodes.  As far as the insurance they may note that you have not followed up with mammos and this may go against you.  Having a negative mammo would certainly be on you side.  They may have you seen by one of their doctors.  Reconsider the mammos.  Knowledge is sometimes power and the lack thereof could kill you.
Posts.Title: Breast calcifications

Posts.Content: I guess you have to do what you have to do. It is a shame it has to be this way.  Is it health insurance that you are trying to obtain?  or Life insurance?  Either way I hope your strategy works for you in the long run.
Posts.Title: Breast calcifications

Posts.Content: It sounds as though this is not something you normally experience unless it is related to your cycle.  I had fibrocystic disease so it was not uncommon to have tenderness.  Do you have a strong history of BC?  Since you are already scheduled to see you OB/GYN in January it is probably safe to wait but make sure you mention it at that time even if it goes away.  If you continue to have additional symptoms over the next few weeks then you may want to call them and discuss it further.  Sometimes you can develop and infection of the breast.  Hope this is helpful.
Posts.Title: do I need to go to the doctor?

Posts.Content: There is no right answer that anyone else can give.  It is a personal thing.  You already have seen your mom deal with BC so it sounds as though you have been thinking about this for some time.  Removing more tissue and having radiation was a good alternative for me with only one breast involved but it has its drawbacks.  I had lost so much tissue and radiation continues to shrink the remaining breast tissue so I had to wear a prosthesis over my remaining breast for a year until I could have reconstruction in the form of implants.  Then due to the large scar in the middle of my breast the implant did take properly the first attempt and I had a second surgery to soften the scar so the implant fell into a more normal placing.  Today, I'm very satisfied with the results but it was a process as well.  I still have to go for yearly mammo's and ultrasounds due to the implants and face the possibility of a local or widespread recurrence.  I do not have any family history of BC.  Your alternative may be a good choice in your situation,  It certainly will be a bigger surgery and longer recovery but since you have stage 0 meaning it has not broken through the ducts what you are considering may actually offer a cure.  If you were to opt for a lumpectomy they would have to obtain clear margins around the entire area or mastectomy would have to be done in that event as well.  When all is said and done, you have to do what is best for you!
Posts.Title: DCIS and treatment choice

Posts.Content: Hi!  I had BC diagnosed in 9/03 and having been doing well, on Femara, originally had a lumpectomy and radiation.  During the past 4 years I have had low iron levels diagnosed on two occasions.  The first it was extremely low and I had to get a gasto work up. I was on iron therapy and my levels stabilized so I stopped iron. Recently, found out again my ferritin levels have dropped so I'm back on iron but have no idea what may be causing this.  I had a total hysterectomy years ago so that isn't the culprit.  Wondering if anyone out there has a similar story or know the possible cause.
Posts.Title: low iron levels?

Posts.Content: I also had stage l invasive ductal carcinoma that was small with no lymph node involvement, also positive estrogen/progesterone.  My choices of treatment were either mastectomy or lumpectomy with radiation, notice I mention radiation with lumpectomy.  Lumpectomy is not considered a complete procedure.  There can always be residual microscopic cells left behind even after obtaining clear margins as they did in my case as well.  Keep in mind all you need is one cell left behind and the whole process begins again.  You 5 yr. cure rate only goes to 90+% if you do either the mastectomy or the lumpectomy with radiation, otherwise, you compromise your chances of a recurrence.  Meds such as Femara or Tamoxifen are considered adjunct therapies.  Radiation is considered primary treatment with lumpectomy at the inital diagnosis.  It is not that bad, a little inconvenience for a lot of benefit.
Posts.Title: Radiation after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Glad to help!
Posts.Title: Radiation after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: I don't understand your doctor's logic.  I too had left bc with lumpectomy and radiation, and breast implants a year after radiation.  My surgeon told me that if I had a recurrence in that breast that a mastectomy would have to be done along with chemo.  By removing the breast you cut down the chance of a recurrence although not entirely.  Why would you wait for the presence of any tumor before action as it only takes one cell to break away from an invasive tumor to create havoc.  Once the cancer has left the breast and lymph node area there is no longer any chance of cure.  Get a second opinion.
Posts.Title: ?Would hyperbaria help riadiated tissue from bc so I can have a mastectomy.

Posts.Content: Hi Hollyhobby! I'm sorry to hear you haveto face BC.  I know you must be scared.  Stage 1 BC is highly treatable and the prognosis is very good.  I was diagnosed with stage 1 in Sept. 2003 and also had a lumpectomy with radiation.  With a lumpectomy the idea is to get what is referred to as "clear margins" which means what it implies, normal tissue surrounding the entire tumor area.  If this is obtained they probably will do a sentinel node biopsy to determine if the cancer has not spread to the nodes.  I actually had a node dissection which is a little more involved but I faired well with this procedure also.  Just had to do some exercises which helps prevent any complication such as lymphadema which is rare with sentinel node biopsy, and it addresses the soreness and stiffness accompanied with it.  Depending on the size of your affected breast there may hardly be anything but a scar.  One note I would like to mention with radiation therapy the treated breast will tend to pull back or shrink if you will so if this is a concern discuss it with your surgeon.  I ended up having breast reconstruction with implants with good results.  The method of radiation which lasts for about 7 weeks, although I understand there is a shorter course with higher doses some places may be using with good success is not bad.  I looked at it like having another part time job and actually drove myself every day an hour away.  The treatment itself lasts a couple minutes.  You may get some irritation in the form of redness.  I have very sensitive skin so I asked my radiologist for something at the onset.  She prescribed Biafine and it worked wonders.  I only had a little pink discoloration and it goes away after treatment gradually.  If you have radiation and you feel you may need reconstruction it can't be done for about a year after treatment so discuss this with your surgeon.  A couple weeks into radiation therapy you probably will feel very tired.  It is a different tired, like early in the day you have filled your gas tank and about 2:00 or so it it empty and you just can't go anymore, you need to rest. This is normal and eventually after finished treatment it will pass.  I continued to work part time job and was able to do so but by the time I got home and hit the couch I couldn't move any more the rest of the night.  There are so many support groups, take advantage of them.  For a time your life will seem like doctors and hospitals and you may feel somewhat detached from the rest of the world but be assured this will pass and believe me life will be normal again, it may be a new normal but just know things will be okay again.  I'm post menapausal so I was also placed on a anticancer hormone Femara which I take daily and tolerate very well.  Some people don't tolerate it as well.  I know this seems like an arduous process and it is but it is only temporary.  I was recently diagnosed with thryoid cancer, no connection to my BC and will have to go through another arduous process but again I have to remind myself there is light beyond the tunnel.  Good luck!  I hoped this has helped.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Marilyn,  Your post was quite intriging.  As far as an estrogen blocker.  If you have ER positive tumor it is necessary to block all estrogen production in you system.  It is not about a balance anymore.  The estrogen will feed or fuel any remaining cells or recurrence so it is definitely to your advantage to take one of the anti-estrogen blockers.  I'm on Femara and have had no ill side effects although I understand there are some who do.  What is intriguing it that you also have been diagnosed with thryoid cancer.  How did they determine that?  I also developed thryoid cancer and they estimate the process started about the same time my BC was diagnosed.  Unfortunately, it wasn't discovered until just recently and I'm now classified as stage 3 for the thyroid cancer, stage l for the breast as that was caught early.  It would be interesting to know if you have a family history of either breast or thyroid cancer.  I do not.  I'm actually in the process of asking my insurance co. to cover a blood test that links breast and thryoid cancer to a particular syndrome so it is very interesting that this has also happened to you.  I'm in my 50's.  If I may ask how old are you?  Would love to hear back!  Also the Femara does not complicate your treatment for thryoid cancer.  I was on Cytomel and felt good, will be going through RAI next week and then will be given Levoxyl to replace my thyroid function.  Hopes this helps!
Posts.Title: Progesterone treatment for ER positive Breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi!  I'm so sorry to hear your mom had to go through all this a second time.  And to hear how much this is upsetting you.  As far as radiation, you can only radiate one area one time.  For example I had my left breast radiated after diagnosed with BC almost 4 years ago and the doctor told me if the cancer would to recur in the same breast I would have to have a mastectomy because that would be the only way locally to control the disease.  If it would to recur in the opposite breast I could receive radiation so the fact they can no longer radiate doesn't suggest that there is nothing more than can be done.  Radiation goes after any left behind cancer cells in a given area with the intent to find and kill them but it does not address any cells that have left that area. Chemotherapy would address this, unfortunately, it is much harsher then radiation.  I don't know your age but there are many support groups out there and hospitals offer sessions where they address various topics involved with BC.  Can you talk to your mom about what her doctor's are saying, or maybe you can go with her and have the doctor address any concerns you and she may have.  Worrying unfortunately changes nothing.  It is more important that you both take an active role in dealing with her disease and enjoy one another.  Do those things you've always wanted to do.  Ask the doctor how she can address her tiredness in hopes of feeling better so you both can accomplish this.  I know how terrifying all this can be but try to find some normalcy in your life and treat this just as something she has to deal with in her life but allow life to go on.  Best wishes!
Posts.Title: concern for mom after chemo,need help please!

Posts.Content: Hi!  There is a mutation, I believe, that shows a connection between breast and melanoma as well as pancreatic and some other cancers.  I also had Brac 1 & Brac 2 testing which was negative and a second series called the "Colaris".  The genetic counselor also wanted me to do a third series but this was not yet an approved series by my insurance carrier.  I'm not sure if it falls under the "Colaris" series or the one I was denied.  I was diagnosed with melanoma many years ago which was later reversed but I do have a propensity for it.  Had a first cousin who had it and have what they term as severe dysplastic nevi.  Have you seen the dermatologist yet?  These two cancers act entirely different however.  But your wise in getting the lesion checked out.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer & Melanoma

Posts.Content: Thanks for responding!  We're about the same age.  I'm 58.  It sounds as though you did have the thyroid cancer before your BC but in my case it is almost as if it developed at the same time, like something derailed per as my genetic counselor commented.  I have read an association between the RAI treatment for thryoid cancer increasing the occurrence of BC but what other relationship are you referring as you have not had RAI as yet?  It is interesting you indicate that while going through radiation for your breast (which is part 2 of the initial treatment when you have surgery and lumpectomy, you can avoid radiation if you opt for mastectomy but it is not a choice with lumpectomy as there is too great a chance for remnant cells to be left behind in the breast tissue), that your neck swelled.  I asked my rad onc. if while doing the radiation on my breast and axillary area if it could have hit the isthmus or thyroid.  She didn't feel that was the case and indicated usually with radiation exposure it takes at least 5 years to show.  Have you heard different?  No one that I know with BC is on progesterin as I mentioned.  If you are ER positive you are probably progesterin positive as well meaning neither hormone is good for your type of BC, of matter of fact, it is harmful but I may be in error.  Although most thyroid cancer is slow growing such as the common type of papillary, don't be fooled, there are other types which are much more agressive even in the papillay diagnosis such as mine which is a subtype of papillary "tall cell".  I only had at largest a 1.3 cm nodule and it was most aggressive invading the isthmus and leaving the thyroid capsule into the fat tissue and in one node in the center compartment but leaving the node capsule and I still have at least one positive 4mm node in my neck region which still has to be addressed.  And in my case it probably only has been present 3 to 4 years and I'm still stage 3.  Cancer in any part of your body is nothing to take lightly nor play the odds.  Better be agressive without overkill up front then to give it a better opportunity to take hold then there may not be much hope only to extend a decent quality of life.  Good luck with your pathology report, hope it is good news, being the common variety papillary type.  And you are definitely doing the right thing with radiation, after all if you had not gone through this process your thyroid cancer may not have discovered until it was doing the bad things mine has attempted to do and I'm still lucky as it could have been worse.  I would like to keep in touch as we have a lot in common hear.  By the way the name of the syndrome is "Cowden Syndrome", you can check it out on line and you don't have to have all the symptoms.
Posts.Title: Progesterone treatment for ER positive Breast cancer

Posts.Content: Your situation sounds oh so familiar. I also had a hysterectomy before starting on Premarin for, at that time the science community believed, heart benefit, to decrease the risk of osteoporosis and hot flashes. As you are probably aware it does not provide any heart benefit, and I actually developed osteoporosis and osteopenia while on Premarin. I must admit it did address the hot flashes. I stayed on estrogen for l0 years to one of my primary doctors dismay, but my OB/GYN was in agreement. I stopped a month before I read that there was a connection with women taking estrogen long term, more than a couple years, and the develop- ment of breast cancer. I didn't stop soon enough. When I found out that the treatment for most breast cancers were anti-estrogen drugs it was a no brainer for me. I was angry that my doctors didn't take this more seriously. I also have no history of breast cancer in my family but there is colon and melanoma. Colon cancer is more likely to develop in woman with breast cancer and vice versa, as well as ovarian. I know hot flashes and night sweats can drive one crazy, I continue to deal with them although not as bad as first going off estrogen. One thing for sure, hot flashes and night sweats won't kill you but dealing with the traumatic diagnosis of breast cancer and the ever present worry of a recurrence can. I would suggest you do your own research and get another opinion regarding the relationship between breast cancer. If you were not having breast difficulty I might agree with your doctor but if you indeed have an early stage cancer the doctor's will have you stop it as it causes the tumor to grow. Hopefully, this will be a false alarm but one you should consider about what to do and take in the future. I just don't want you to end up like me. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Unknown

Posts.Content: Just wanted to add, macrocalcifications (large calcifications)are more often benign but microcalcifications are more indicative of cancer.
Posts.Title: Breast calcifications

Posts.Content: Before having radiation several years ago I mentioned to my radiation oncologist that I was concerned because I had such sensitive skin.  She gave me Biafine cream for radiated areas and this helped to keep down the redness.  By the end of my treatments my breast was pink but I avoided the extreme redness and discomfort that goes along with it.
Posts.Title: Treatment Of Radiation Burns

Posts.Content: My last mammo they also did an ultrasound.  Mammo was okay but my ultrasound showed what they call a "complex cyst".  The doctor explained that it is quite common to have cysts and they can normally tell by the property of the cyst whether it is indeed a benign cyst or something more.  There were some dark specs she pointed out in mine which put in into the classification of a complex cyst.  The protocal is to have them (complex cysts)  aspirated as there is a small chance it could be cancerous.  If you are seeing someone who deals with womans health they probably can distinguish whether there is a concern at this time but ask her or him point blank what they feel the cysts reveal, if any of them can be deemed "complex".  If you hear this word then push to have it aspirated.  When aspirated the fluid should come out and it should be clear or straw colored.  If it draws blood or is solid that a biopsy is indicated.  Hope this infor helps.
Posts.Title: Cysts found on Mammo/Ultrasound

Posts.Content: I too had been taken Premarin for ten years and at the ten year mark developed breast cancer. There is no familiar history. I believe there is an ongoing study on estrogen only drugs to see the actual relationship it plays. I know there is at least a hint that long term use of ERT plays a role. I haven't heard any connection with dementia. If you understand the role that breastcancer therapy such as Tamoxifen and Armidex etc. play, working as ANTI-estrogen, it baffles me why there is still question whether the reverse, given menapausal women estrogen long term can play a role in the development of breast cancer. Once the study results are released it may add support and then you may find attorneys willing to take a case but you need support for a claim. Good luck! I would be interested to know how you make out.
Posts.Title: Premarin Only Lawsuits

Posts.Content: The radiation won't affect your bone density.  As I said though Femara, one of the adjunct oral cancer drugs may, so if your medical oncologist chooses this category of meds after radiation then I would start taking calcium supplements about 1200 to 1500 mg and Vit. D about 400 to 600 but there are other drugs used that do not adversely affect the bone such as Tamoxifen or the new drug Avista.  If you don't already I would take a good multivitamin with mineral supplement, eat a good diet and your body will tell you when you need to rest which is important because the body needs energy to effectively use the radiation.  For skin redness etc. I started using Biafine radiation cream at the onset of my radiation therapy.  This is a prescription cream which worked wonders.  Don't be afraid to address any of these questions with your medical oncologist as well.
Posts.Title: post menopausal 66 yr

Posts.Content: It is interesting your mentioned D3.  My sister mentioned that she was told to take this supplement.  She has a D vitamin deficiency.  I have read several articles pointing to Vit. D as playing a much bigger role in our health then they expected.  Lack of D can lead to serious disease including BC.  You mentioned it addresses inflammation which could also be good for heart patients such as my husband who has CAD.  Thanks for mentioning this.  I never thought of seeking out a nutritionist before cancer treatment.  Had I been told I had to start chemo I probably would have as chemo adversely affects your immune system, the very thing needed to have your meds work to the optimum but I agree if you are concerned this is a good suggestion.
Posts.Title: post menopausal 66 yr

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with stage l BC, estrogen/prog. positive, Her neg. and was post menapausal at that time 4 years ago.  I had a lumpectomy (plus) and an additional biopsy in that breast at that time.  After surgery I went through 7 weeks of radiation and then started Femara which was the new kid on the block.  Because I also have osteoporosis and Femara can deplete calcium I get Zometa infusions, in the beginning every 4 months  now every 6 months as I cannot take Fosamax like medication due to GERD.  If you can tolerate Fosamax type meds this would be the first choice.  You should have a bone density if you have not already to see if you are currently suffering from osteoporosis or osteopenia particulary if you are placed on Femara.  There has been a new osteoporosis drug which has recently been approved for BC patients as well, Avista.  It works in a similar fashion as the estrogen inhibitor drugs plus it gives you the benefit of protecting bone health.  I've tolerated the Femara very well and have been on it 3 years now but you medical oncologist will choose the best for your particular situation.  These added drugs definitely show a benefit when taken after surgery and radiation treatment.  Hope this helps!
Posts.Title: post menopausal 66 yr

Posts.Content: It's the truth Jill, I had to learn more about BC than I ever wanted to know.  Now I'm learning about thyroid cancer, diagnosed with that in 8/07 and waiting blood results as I speak which will determine if I need further treatment or what.  Good luck to you.  So glad to hear that one of the tumors was benign and you are still level 1 or 2 which is good.  I had an ultrasound last January and it showed a "complex cyst", mammo was normal.  After needle aspiration it came back benign.  Great news but it never really ends.
Posts.Title: Opposite breast cancer

Posts.Content: I recently found out that a lady who worked with my husband in her mid 60's was diagnosed with a lung nodule.  A mammo and physical exam revealed many breast lymphs.  She was to go in to have a biopsy.  Over this past weekend it was found that she was also in kidney failure, not sure whether the cancer had also affected the kidney but once she is released from the hospital the doctors recommended Hospice.  This tells us she has less than 6 months probably much less considering she is in kidney failure.  Actually, this will be a blessing as she may not have to suffer as long.  I understand she is now experiencing pain.  I would say that your gran is probably in an equal situation and her kidney will also start to fail.  Considering her age and the severity of her disease I would do whatever necessary to make her as comfortable as possible.
Posts.Title: What to expect

Posts.Content: Whether one will remain cancer free is the $900.00 question.  The fact that it did not appear to have spread beyond the breast means she may never have another episode but there is always a possibility of spread to another area and all is needed is one breast cancer tissue cell remaining to develop a new tumor or spread to the lymph nodes.  There is never a guarantee just like there is never a guarantee in life.  The main thing for your friend is to keep her appointments with her team and report any new unusual findings.  But for now I would rejoice that she is currently disease free and doing well.
Posts.Title: is my friend cancer free?

Posts.Content: This is a tough one.  You are definitely experiencing menapause.  Hot flashes/sweats, cold and hot.  I'm also 58.  Unfortunately if you have BC, estrogen is out of the question.  Ask you medical oncologist or one of your doctors.  My radiation oncologist told me I could have a glass of soy milk daily (eeck!) or have one Vit. E tablet daily.  The Vit. E tablet did seem to take the edge off but my medical oncologist says it also has estrogen effects so you have to way your side effects against this information.  I have a fan over my bed at night and it is on every night, summer or winter months.  I have a little table fan in my family room when I am watching TV or reading. It goes on an off several times a night, cold to hot to sweating to cold.  I'm not as bad as I use to be after stopping estrogen therapy before being diagnosed with BC but it may be something you just have to put up with.  But I would ask your cancer team, they may have a suggestion to help.
Posts.Title: Advice on what to do now

Posts.Content: Not sure exactly what your mean but it certainly can come back in the chest area.
Posts.Title: suit of armor

Posts.Content: Sorry Sue, I have no idea about this.  I'm assuming you had a mastectomy.  Is this formation on the bone??  I'm sure you are not unique but it may not be that common.  Good luck in finding the info you need.
Posts.Title: suit of armor

Posts.Content: There is a connection between BC and colon, I'm sure it increases as you get older.  Clinically the doctors are checking lymph nodes in the axillary area (under arms) and in the remaining breasts for swelling or lumps.  I'm sure they are observing any would be weight loss.  Also, my doctors occassionally tap up and down my spine as there were some questions in this area but they are also guided by any complaints.  If you experience and unusual pain bring it to their attention.  They normally do not do routine CAT or bone scans unless there is something that warrants further testing.  MRI is becoming a popular tool in checking the breasts.  It can be used alternating with mammo every other appointment or if anything is suspicious on mammo or ultrasound.  PET is now also being introduced to gage ones spread of the disease and their response to treatment such as chemo.  The truth is, however, I've been told, they have no cure once what one doctor described as the "horse getting out of the barn" or moving beyond the breast and a few local lymph nodes.  They can still achieve cure if it recurrs in breast tissue or the opposite breast but once it attacks bone or organs their role is to contain as long as possible and the treatment is ongoing.
Posts.Title: Followup testing post bc treatment

Posts.Content: read your concern, you are doing the right thing by following your doctor's advise. someone with fibrocystic disease (benign) can develop breast cancer, your lump can be related to either. I have both. you mention you have been on HRT for about 6 years, I was on it for 10 yrs., my advise would be to stop it, particulary if you are peri or menapausal. the adjunct therapies such as tamoxifen and femara given to woman diagnosed with breast cancer are anti-estrogen drugs. finding a breast cancer at an early stage is your best chance for cure, 95 to 98% for the 5 yr. survival rate. I know it is terribly frightening and upseting to pursue this but chances are everything is okay and if by some remote chance there is a problem you and your doctor are right on top of it and you'll be fine either way. best of luck!
Posts.Title: Unknown

Posts.Content: I don't know if I can answer your question completely.  I had a lumpectomy plus, along with 2 biopsies and an infection so I lost a lot of breast tissue.  I had radiation and as a result of the radiation the breast continues to pull back onto the chest (my surgeon refers to radiation as the gift that keeps on giving).  I had to wait a year after radiation because other than the skin that undergoes some damage, internally, I've been told has to heal as well.  After a year I had implants put in using a combo expander/implant.  It worked pretty well.  The scar area across the center of my breast needed a second surgery, what my plastic surgeon referred to as softening the scar).  That did well for about 3 years and the breast around the scar area is starting to pull again so I'm actually scheduled for fat replacement from my stomach next week to fill in the pulled area.  Radiation can pose a problem for reconstruction so you should discuss this with your doctor ahead of time, however, I had stage 1 bc.  The first concern should be addressing the BC and being aggressive.  Once it reaches stage 4 (metastatic disease) there is no turning back.  The best of luck to you.
Posts.Title: Needing advice...Radiation after double mast w/expanders

Posts.Content: No, No don't be concerned about the radiation.  I would agree that head & neck patient's have a difficult time but for breast cancer patient's it is not bad at all.  I have sensitive skin to boot so I asked my radiation oncologist for something to put on my skin.  She gave me Biafine for radiated skin and I used it right away as directed and it worked very well.  The most I had was some pink which eventually faded.  The sunburn effect was minimal.  I would ask before hand for the cream, it really works.
Posts.Title: Radiation therapy

Posts.Content: It concerns me that you have concerns and questions about your treat-ment.  You have the right to have all the information about your treatment options upfront so when all is said and done you are a major player in your decisions whether it be to opt for a mastectomy or any other type of treatment.  I was diagnosed with stage l, no lymph involvement, that arose from ductal in-situ to invasive.  I had the choice of lympectomy and radiation, considered as one mode of treatment, or mastectomy.  After the lump was stained and screened I was told chemo might be an overkill in my case, but as the tumor was estrogen and progesterone positive and I'm postmenapausal, treatment with hormonal therapy was recommended. I'm on Femara.  I opted for lumpectomy w/rad. by the way but this is a personal decision.  That was 3 years ago.  I agree with the person that suggested you get a 2nd, 3rd if necessary until you understand what your particular options are before proceeding.  Write your questions down as they come to you as this is a very difficult and confusing time.  If the doctor's you are now seeing won't answer your questions to your satisfaction or forget just whose body is in jeopardy, I would advise you seek someone else who will. You have the right to feel comfortable with your decision and you can't do that unless someone is allowing you to partner in your care and answering your questions and addressing your concerns.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Stage iv - no Surgery

Posts.Content: On 7/1/2007 Hope72 wrote: I was diagnosed with breast cancer a couple of weeks ago, although it seems like years.  A surgeon removed  two lumps, one through wire masectomy and another he couldn't see, but felt.  I also had another section of tissue removed in the nipple region, as I'd been having a discharge from the nipple.  The pathology report stated that the tissue by the breast is intraductal carcinoma in situ, Grade 2.  The lump with the wire is grade 3 infiltrating duct cell carcinoma and the tissue close to it is grade 2 infiltrating duct cell carcinoma.  I am scheduled for a modified radical masectomy in 10 days.  The surgeon doesn't know how many lymph nodes he will remove but says the sentinel node biopsy had been found to be less effective than was previously thought.I would like to get some opinions on whether his planned course of treatment seems reasonable, based on the above.  I've been reading about lymphadema and it sounds depressing.  My surgeon says he's never had a case turn up after one of his surgeries involving lymph node removal. Thank you.   Hi!  I had a lumpectomy and second biopsy of the same breast 3 & l/2 yrs. ago for BC stage 1 and my surgeon did a node ressection (11 nodes)rather than the sentinel node, not sure why but I just wanted to tell you yes, it does increase the incidence of lymphadema but if you do the exercises after surgery as instructed it will help,  They will instruct you not to have blood drawn from this arm after the procedure and to be careful of any infection in that arm as this can predispose you to lymphadema. I have not had a problem and the scar healed very well and quickly.  If you are not comfortable with his answer however, seek a second opinion.  I believe it helps if you are in on the decision making process when suitable and this is suitable.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Questions about upcoming surgery

Posts.Content: First, I'm glad to hear you are having things checked out.  Don't know your age or familiar history or problems you are having.  There are conditions when you are younger that can cause painfull breast particularly around your cycle.  Fibrocystic breast which has cyst formation can be quite painfull.  These are benign situations and you can check with your doctor on what latest treatments there are to help.  If you have a specific problem such as a palpable lump or redness or discharge this could indicate a more serious problem, however, here again it doesn't necessarily indicate a malignancy but certainly you would want to follow up on any of these problems.  When uncertain check with your doctor is the best advise I can give you.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: I need Help.

Posts.Content: Hi Anni!  Sorry you are going through all this emotional pain and anxiety.  You are right as far as risk factor, with your familiar history, your risk is much higher, and you mentioned colon and ovarian cancer in your familar history.  They have found a connection between these and breast cancer.  There are syndromes that link these together.  Genetic counseling would help here.  As far as the problem with your left breast.  I have learned that we know our bodies better than anyone.  Something is telling you to pursue this, I would.  One possible symptom mentioned as worisome is a breast that changes shape or size.  When you meet with the surgeon, he or she will probably have you fill out a medical questionnaire.  They will ask about family history of cancer.  I have found out in my journey that most doctor's do not refer to this so reiterate to the surgeon about your mother and those blood family members who have had ovarian or colon, and your personal history of polyps.  This should get his or her attention if their degree is worth anything.  Point blank talk to them about the change in breast size and what other causes it could be.  Were the calcifications macocalcifications, which are less worrisome, or microcalcifications which may signal a potential problem as in my case.  If would be helpful if you had your past mammos with you and a copy of the reports.  You should have no problem in requesting and obtaining them.  I would normally advise to get a second opinion if the first leaves you feeling unsure but I understand you no longer have insurance.  Write down any questions that your have as you think of them and take them along and don't leave the office until your questions are put to rest.  Again, a breast that changes in size or shape is a red flag.  I know one time I went into my primary doctors office with no ankle, due to fluid, and I mentioned my swollen ankle and the doctor immediately dismissed it, I guess because he didn't realize that it was not normal for me to not see my ankle.  Some people normally have fuller ankles.  Let us know how you make out.  Hope this was of some help!
Posts.Title: something of concern in recent mamo and ultrasound I'm scared...

Posts.Content: Oh!  I just wanted to add one thing about radiation to the breast, it causes the breast to undergo some shrinkage.  Soon after being diagnosed I decided because of the tissue loss from a two biopsies, lumpectomy and from infection that I would have reconstruction ASAP.  After undergoing my lumpectomy the surgeon said that they didn't rcommend reconstruction on a radiated breast and that the remaining breast would continue to shrink.  Well that was unacceptable to me and I almost went after his juggler for not informing me before my surgery.  I had to wait a year and supplement with a prosthesis but had my reconstruction, implants.  It took some tweaking over a period of months but I am very satisfied with the result.  Something to keep in mind.
Posts.Title: Radiation therapy

Posts.Content: Oh!  I just wanted to add one thing about radiation to the breast, it causes the breast to undergo some shrinkage.  Soon after being diagnosed I decided because of the tissue loss from a two biopsies, lumpectomy and from infection that I would have reconstruction ASAP.  After undergoing my lumpectomy the surgeon said that they didn't rcommend reconstruction on a radiated breast and that the remaining breast would continue to shrink.  Well that was unacceptable to me and I almost went after his juggler for not informing me before my surgery.  I had to wait a year and supplement with a prosthesis but had my reconstruction, implants.  It took some tweaking over a period of months but I am very satisfied with the result.  Something to keep in mind.
Posts.Title: Radiation therapy

Posts.Content: It is not unusual for BC to show up in the opposite breast.  At the time of diagnosis in one breast the new protocol is to have an MRI of the opposite breast before surgery to insure it is not present in that breast as well.  Many doctors have not been doing that but research has shown it is a good protocol.  There are also tumor markers present as in my case which are indicative of a recurrence in either breast.  If it is still confined just to the opposite breast, it is still considered a local occurence and is curable with the proper treatment.  If there has to be a recurrence that is what you would opt to happen.  Once it becomes distant they no longer speak of cure.  Also, recent recommendations for woman who have dense breasts, high risk, (of course, we are) and those of us who have reconstruction with implants should have MRI's.  Yes, they are more inclined to pick up false positives.  That was the situation in my case but like someone else wrote, I would rather go through a few days of uncertainty they have it spread beyond the breast.  Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: Opposite breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi!  Let me see if I can answer some of your questions.  I had the old fashion 5 day a week for actually 7 week total.  The new version that you describe was not quite being used but on the horizon.  This was 4 years ago.  The newer version of course is not as disruptive with you schedule and I believe it is quite effective.  You may even avoid the shrinkage that I mentioned because it is a more targeted therapy rather than radiating the entire breast.  Talk this over with your radiologist.  I think if I had the choice I would have chosen the implanted version.  The shrinkage is just that and it all depends on the size of your remaining breast but it keeps pulling back more to your chest.  The implant surgery would equate to having the lumpectomy, no better, no worse but remember in this case you are putting something back which is important to you so your mental status is positive.  In preparation for the implants, due to my original surgery and radiation which already caused the skin to tighten etc. I needed to have either an expander put in that the doctor fills with saline over a period of time to stretch the skin to prepare for implant or in my case I choose a combination (part saline & part silicone) which meant I only needed one surgery to install.  A mound was already in place and the cosmetic surgeon again would use a saline solution added to stretch the skin until an optimal size.  My scar went across the middle of my breast and it was quite tight and didn't give as well as the remaining breast so I had more fluid going across the top and bottom of the scar.  At some point I had to return for replacement of an implant in the opposite breast (which was placed to bring uniformity to both breast) after it was ruptured doing a core biopsy and the plastic surgeon reopened the scar on the affected breast and softened it so it would take more fluid in the area to balance out the breast.  Three years later it is about 90% of equal fullness so I'm pleased with that.  I lost about 5% over the 3 years.  I believe it is Federal law, not sure but it is NJ law now that insurance must cover reconstructive surgery for a woman who have lost her breast or has sustained a substantial defect as a result of breast cancer.  And this does not have to be done right away.  I hope I have answered your questions.
Posts.Title: Radiation therapy

Posts.Content: You are not alone.  After having a clear mammo and MRI this past Feb. my OB/GYN felt something of "concern".  I have an appointment with my surgeon early this afternoon actually.  It has been 5 years for me with stage 1.  I'll be thinking of you as well.  I also had thyroid cancer which I'm monitored for and have a benign tumor in my inner ear which a surgeon suggests having out.  Never a dull moment as they say.  I say dull would be nice.
Posts.Title: another lump

Posts.Content: Well they could check your thyroid numbers (blood work) easy enough.  I had BC diagnosed 4 years ago this month and was recently diagnosed with thyroid cancer and my numbers were normal.  Strangely enough I asked my endocrinologist when he would estimate the process with my thyroid started as I have stage III thryoid and he said about 3 & l/2 to 4 years ago.  Just about the time of my BC diagnosis.  I thought that coincidental.   The thyroid cancer was found incidentally by the way, had no symptoms.  It is a good idea for anyone to have their thyroid examined periodically for any nodules which could indicate a problem.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifin/Thyroid

Posts.Content: Good news that the ovaries were okay.  What stage BC were you diagnosed with?  II'm guessing since you had a lumpectomy probably it was stage l or 2.  I've never had a PET, maybe if I had after being diagnosed with BC in 2003 it would have showed my left lobe of the thyroid as again my endo estimates that the process started in my thyroid around the same time.  There is a syndrome that links breast cancer to thyroid cancer.  It is very rare and there are other symptoms.  I don't know if I mentioned it before but it is called Cowden's syndrome.  But I beginning to think there may another link, don't know but there seems to be at least a minority number of patient's who are diagnosed with both in a short period of time from one another.  PET scans are very sensitive to any changes so it doesn't necessarily have to mean a thyroid cancer but it will be good to have it checked out.  Of course, cancer is always better found at the earliest possible time.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifin/Thyroid

Posts.Content: Sounds hopefull.  Glad to hear our doctors are taking that extra measure to insure things are okay.  My ultrasound is actually this coming Wed., the 20th.  I had it in my mind it was last Wed., went so much to get up and showered and on my way which is an hour drive only to realize I had the wrong day.  I've got too much of this going on in my life.  I need my own personal medical secretary, funny that is what I actually do for a living.  Well again, best of luck.  My surgeon also felt it had more to do with the surgeries that I have had but my plastic surgeon felt it is better to be safe and investigate further than do a wait and see.  I agree!  Take care Ann and keep my posted.  I'll do the same.  Maybe we will both come out with good results.
Posts.Title: another lump

Posts.Content: No, No don't be concerned about the radiation.  I would agree that head & neck patient's have a difficult time but for breast cancer patient's it is not bad at all.  I have sensitive skin to boot so I asked my radiation oncologist for something to put on my skin.  She gave me Biafine for radiated skin and I used it right away as directed and it worked very well.  The most I had was some pink which eventually faded.  The sunburn effect was minimal.  I would ask before hand for the cream, it really works.
