Posts.Title: Radiation therapy

Posts.Content: Hi!  Unfortunately, I can't help you but I read your post and hoping someone out there can give you info on this type of BC.  So sorry to hear you are going through so much.  I was diagnosed with BC five years this October.  Thus far it is stable.  When were you originally diagnosed and what type and stage?  (if you don't mind).  I was then diagnosed with thyroid cancer last August so I go from one to the other but gratefull thus far things are stable.  I'll keep you in my thoughts and prayers.  Hope some one out ther can offer you some helpful information.
Posts.Title: looking for same kind adenocarcinoma

Posts.Content: Hi Anni!  Sounds like you have a handle on your situation, probably the mammo films from 2002 on are good enough but you will leave no stone unturned.  I writing about your 13 year old grandson.  I work for a dermatologist and it is highly unlikely that the moles they are referring to are of the more serious nature.  It is possible for them to show some atypical changes, some abnormal cell changes, and they are best to be removed.  There is a lesion called a Spitz nevus which by the naked eye has some of the same properties as the more serious melanoma but these are benign lesions.  I mention this because they are more common in young people.  I was diagnosed with melanoma when I was 21 but many, many years later it was diagnosed to be a Spitz nevus which again is benign.  Again, it is highly unlikely that his moles are more serious then having atypical changes but you daughter is right to address them now.  Let me know how they make out.
Posts.Title: something of concern in recent mamo and ultrasound I'm scared...

Posts.Content: I would pursue testing since your were doing well prior to this new occurrence.  Some hospitals have financial counselors on board to help with the affordability.  Don't be afraid to ask.  Also the American Cancer Society advertises so contact them to see if they can lead you in getting financial help so you can be properly be diagnosed and treated.
Posts.Title: question about radiation side effects 11 mo. later

Posts.Content: So sorry to hear about your mom.  If there is spread it is more likely from the BC unless she had melanoma but even still the mode you speak of is associated more with BC.  You should seek a genetic counselor to go over your potential for developing BC with such a strong familiar history.  Your female relatives may carry a mutation such as BRAC l or 2 and you could possibly be tested.  They can discuss options for you so you can take some control over your own future.  Again, I'm so sorry to hear about your mother.
Posts.Title: Mom had breast cancer in remission now spots in liver and lung after 1 month?.

Posts.Content: I will be having a breast ultrasound and possibly a second mammo pending if they need additional clarity on Wednesday also.  I'll be thinking of you and I'll say a little prayer. Please think of me as well.  Good luck to both of us.  Keep in touch and let me know how you make out.
Posts.Title: another lump

Posts.Content: Went back and read your post again and saw that it began as invasive lobular carcinoma.  Did you try keying in this type of cancer using google, I'm sure there is some sight which can give you some information.
Posts.Title: looking for same kind adenocarcinoma

Posts.Content: I know of someone who was diagnosed stage 4 about 14+ years ago.  She, however, found a clinic up in NY, (we live in NJ) and went completely natural.  Do not know her exact regimen but obviously it has worked.  Also just read about a local women who was told she had 6 months to live 5 years ago and is now another 5 years beyond that, who is also doing an alternative treatment in cleansing the body which includes supplements and a special diet etc.  The paper noted she has over 300 followers she has helped.  Unfortunately, I can't find the article someone recently gave me.  God has given us powers of healing but we must ask Him for His guidance.  I know there are others out there.  Keep the faith and be proactive in you care.
Posts.Title: New Stage 4

Posts.Content: I can relate.  After having a lumpectomy, two biopsies, an infection which caused additional tissue loss and radiation, there wasn't much tissue left on an initially small breast.  I had a combination expander/implant placed.  It had to be injected with saline and as the lumpectomy scar goes across the center of the breast and was tight, the liquid would fill above the breast as you mentioned.  This made me quite self conscious because I knew there was this higher than normal mound on the one side.  My girlfriend gave me a pair of fake breasts and I would place one over the remaining expanding breast tissue to help create symmetry when I wore clothing.  It helped but there wasn't much I could do about the high mound, eventully the solution was adjusted and my cosmetic surgeon softened the scar across the breast to allow everything to take a more normal positioning.  I'm very pleased with the final result. What we have to go through!
Posts.Title: Big cleavage on being reconstructed side only,

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed 4 years ago and on Femara.  I too am at my heaviest and and even after 3 months in a gym program I lost some inches and started to shape but never really lost pounds.  Had to stop for 2 months due to surgery and have gained again.  Seems if I eat anything my weight gets up there, very frustrating.  I use to be a rail when younger.  Medications can play a role I understand.
Posts.Title: Weight Gain

Posts.Content: Most breast cysts are benign.  Some cysts can be complex cysts which means they show some properties on ultrasound that may be questionable.  I recently had an aspiration on a very small cyst that showed on ultrasound but it had some white areas enclosed so  aspiration was indicated.  If it looks benign on ultrasound they don't need to aspirate unless it is painfull or there is other cause.  When aspirating if the fluid comes out clear, straw colored or greenish without blood it is considered benign particularly if it deflates upon removing of fluid, otherwise, if still questionable biopsy is indicated.  I read where most benign cysts are larger, mine was small.  As for the hypoechoic solid nodule you would have to refer to your doctor.  It may indicate a need for biopsy or follow up.
Posts.Title: Hypoechoic Nodule/Cysts

Posts.Content: I've been on Femara for 4 years and have not suffered any hair loss nor any other adverse side effects.  Some women do suffer from joint pains etc. from reading the feed back but it is not like the chemo you are on.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Femara and return of hair after chemo

Posts.Content: Hi!  Did you have radiation to that breast when first diagnosed?  I was told if I had a recurrence in the same radiated breast then mastectomy would be the course of action, however, I met a woman who had a breast cancer about 10 years ago and had a lumpectomy.  Had a recurrence in the same breast and had a second lumpectomy with radiation and has been doing well.  You can probably get info from your local cancer center about reconstruction after mastectomy.  I had received videos of actual pictures and stories. Good luck!
Posts.Title: treatment options

Posts.Content: Hi Stephanie! I'm so sorry you are going through this. Your doctor can give you pain medication. There is no need for you to be in so much pain. I've had two needle localizations plus excisional biopsies. Good luck tomorrow. If you are going back to his office vs. a telephone call, make sure you have someone with you. Sometimes these things can get complex and you may need someone to help you take in all the information. Let me know how you make out. I'll say a prayer that all is clear but write back if you need to.
Posts.Title: While im Waiting For my Results

Posts.Content: Hi! I'm sorry to hear about your sister. What a trooper she seems to be. You mention the diagnosis of breast cancer and tumors in the lung. Any time cancer moves from one part of the body to another it is not a good thing. I'm sure her doctor's are doing what they can to try to keep it under control. I believe you mention your sister takes care of everyone. Are you much younger than she? She obviously doesn't want this to be everyones problem and is more interested in living her life by focusing on the people around her. Just let her know how much she means to you and enjoy your time together. The rest is in God's hands.
Posts.Title: Should i be Concerned

Posts.Content: I don't think Arimidex is the culprit but obviously something abnormal has occurred.  It could be related to the surgery, maybe you body is rejecting, or scar tissue is forming, definitely go back to your surgeon.
Posts.Title: breast reconstruction and arimidex

Posts.Content: Hi!  I work for a doctor but I'm not a medical doctor just a patient.  I have had breast cancer found on mammo identified by micro calcifications but I also was recently diagnosed with thyroid cancer.  This forms nodules in and around your thryoid gland which may or may not be felt by you.  I also have a cancerous nodule that showed up on ultrasound in the neck lymph nodes.  Thryoid can also present in the upper chest.  Of course, breast is one type of cancer associated with swollen or noticeable nodes in the axillary area.  My point is you really need to get one biopsied to get a definitve diagnosis.  No matter what type of cancer it may be and it could possibly be something unrelated, that particular type cancer cell will show up in the biopsy, no matter where the displaced lymph node or tumor, a biopsy will discern.  Best of luck!  Hopefully, you just have some infection process going on and this will just be temporary.
Posts.Title: nodules

Posts.Content: You inherit genes from both your mom and dad so yes you can have your dad's maternal genes but you may not.  If a male blood relative has prostrate cancer this can also be related to breast.  There are other types of cancer which could also be related if you have certain syndromes.  I like someone else who posted do not have a family history of BC but was also diagnosed 4 years ago.  Statistics show most woman who develop BC have no history in their family.  But if there is a strong history, you have an increased chance in developing this disease.  Hope this helps!  All woman are at risk and it increases with age whether prior history or not.
Posts.Title: question about breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Joan!  Yes, I take Zometa infusions, at first every 3 months, now every 6 months.  Zometa is the same component as Fosamax but more potent as it is given intravenously.  I have read some research that shows it is a good drug to stabilize bone.  Several months after being diagnosed a bone scan showed uptake in my spine which after 6 worrying weeks was found not to be related.  But one year later a second bone scan showed a spot on my rib followed by a 6 month scan that showed two additional spots on the opposite rib.  I had only been diagnosed with stage 1 so it was confusing to my doctors. I did have some soreness in the rib area but I have no symptoms today, have not had a follow up scan, but 4 years later have no indication of mets.  Was it the Zometa??  Don't know but I feel it had something to do with it.  As for the problem in the jaw bone.  I actually met the doctor who first discovered this problem, necrosis of the jawbone.  Just don't have any teeth removed.  The problem is more likely to come about if teeth are removed, otherwise, it is very unlikely you would have to worry about this.  With bone mets it is more prudent to address this and make any attempt to keep it under raps because it can spread quickly not only to bone but other internal organs.  If you were me that would be my only concern now.  Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: Zometta Intervenous Treaments

Posts.Content: Hi Rett!  Hoping you would post. Last time I heard from you, you had posted a beautiful poem "When Life Puts a Mountain in Your Way...".  If you get this I would love to hear how you are doing.  Hope all is well. Leemg
Posts.Title: looking for Rett1954

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with stage 1 in Sept. 03, had a bone scan at that time which showed something going on in my spine (suspicious for mets). A follow up bone scan showed a spot on one rib and yet a 3rd showed an additional 2 spots on my ribs (questionable for mets again)and the spinal area was no longer suspicious. An abdominal scan also revealed probable cysts on my liver. I also take Calcium supplements and Vit. D and take Zometa infusions not for bone mets but for osteoporosis. My point, even though these tests have come back confirming probable mets because of my diagnosis of BCC the tests are so sensitive that they can pick up other things giving a false positive. So far my doctor's have declared me mets free and will not do any more testing unless I become symptomatic clinically or otherwise. Ask for further confirmation of these results before giving up hope. Even with the possibility they confirm mets, I understand from others that you can live for a very long time with treatment. Good luck!
Posts.Title: i Need Your Help...

Posts.Content: Courtney, don't know your situation.  Did you have a lumpectomy?  I had a lumpectomy and had radiation.  As my doctor has indicated, radiation is the gift that keeps on giving, meaning it will continue to pull the breast towards the chest wall.  I had an implant but have a large scar in the middle of my breast where I also developed an infection and lost a lot of breast tissue.  Originally, it was so tight that the implant would not lay properly.  My cosmetic surgeon reopened the scar to soften it somewhat and this did help the implant to take on a more normal position.  You will probably never get a perfect result but you can get a good result.  You can always seek a second opinion due to your insurance situation before making a decision.
Posts.Title: scar tissue and indentation surgery

Posts.Content: A lumpectomy isn't complete without radiation to kill any trace cancer cells left behind.  You either do a mastectomy or lumpectomy and radiation.  Don't discount the oral drugs either.  Some of us don't experience any side effects and the benefits are great.  Not only do they help prevent a recurrence in the affected breast but help to prevent mets.  I would opt for the above therapy before ever considering chemo.  One day you may not have the option but if you do, radiation and hormone drugs would be my choice.
Posts.Title: Chemo vs. Estrogen Inhibitor drugs

Posts.Content: My understanding it that you can not have radiation to the same area more than once.  I had radiation to my left breast and should I have a recurrence in the right I could have radiation to that breast but should there be a recurrence in the affected breast, mastectomy and chemo would be indicated.  If it has spread to the bone unless used for paliative (sp?) care, radiation would probably not be indicated.  Most likely, chemo would be the choice of treatment.
Posts.Title: Information please.

Posts.Content: I did not have chemo as such, had surgery, radiation and taking Femara, also get a Zometa infusion now every 6 months.
Posts.Title: strange side effects

Posts.Content: Tamoxifen has been around a very long time and was the gold standard until such drugs as Femara, Arimidex came on the market. They work in different ways however. Are you premenapausal?  I've been on Femara for 5 years and am postmenapausal.  As someone else mentioned some people like myself suffer no ill side effects while others have some debilitating symptoms.  You can't tell where you will be until you are on the medication.  Both type of medications are effective in preventing recurrence and I know Femara also prevents BC in the other breast and mets to some degree.  Hope this info helps.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Any one on Hormonal Therapy

Posts.Content: Not aware that there are two different types of bone.  It can harbor within the bone marrow before releasing and attaching to bone.  My understanding is that once it metastasizes there is no cure but treatment is aimed at relieving pain, slowing progression and maintaining function. Thankfully, haven't reached that point so can not give you specific info.  regarding mets to the bone.
Posts.Title: Bone metastasis

Posts.Content: You are doing the right thing and having it checked out.  Any time there is an unknown cause for a lump or swelling it should be investigated ASAP.   Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: should i be worried?

Posts.Content: What medicine are you taking??  Arimidex or it's cousin??  I'm on Femara and no I am fortunate enough to have tolerated it well, however, I have read many sights where ladies complain of bone pain and worse from these drugs.  I'm also on Zometa which is a bone building drug for osteoporosis and I'm wondering if this helps to address this.  Products such as Bonita, can't think of the other, begins with a F address osteoporosis as well as Zometa which I take by infusion.  They use Zometa for bone cancer as well.  Don't know if they could play a role in your case, don't think they have been studied for this but I certainly would start if not already taking calcium supplements and Vit. D which is needed for absorbtion of D.  I don't know if anti-inflammatories would help but I just read an article that these are being proven to reduce the occurrence of BC.  I have stomach issues so I can not rely on them.  There are others on this board who have delt with complications from these medicine and hopefully they will respond.
Posts.Title: Bone pain

Posts.Content: Your story is heartwrenching.  I can't tell you how sorry I am.  Have you asked your doctors about any trials that may be going on that you could participate.  Also I would check into breast cancer trials on line to see where they are being conducted.  I know your need to be proactive especially for your daughter.  I'll keep you and your daughter in my prayers as well.  Best of luck to you and may God be with you and show you the way!
Posts.Title: Cancer recurred in lungs after treatment of IBC

Posts.Content: I would do a biopsy.  There are various types of biopsy procedures, some needle.  If it has grown I would want to know and not wait.  An MRI may show another view of the lesion which again would say go directly to biopsy or follow up.  If I had an MRI and it was at all questionable I would have it in the back of my head, thinking what if it is bc and I'm waiting.  A biopsy will be definitive and then it can either be addressed or put to rest.  Best of luck with your decision.
Posts.Title: Screening Question

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with stage l BC 4 years ago, no chemo but on Femara and diagnosed with thyroid cancer this past June and just finished treatment for that.  Back in April for no known reason I started having a swooshing sound in my right ear which was actually my heart beat and moderate hearing loss that went along with it.  Went to two ENT and they said I experienced sudden hearing loss which could be attributed to a virus or some unknown cause.  Unfortunately, if it is nerve related as in my case there is nothing they can do short of recommending a hearing device.  Sometimes there is no real rhyme or reason for this problem.
Posts.Title: strange side effects

Posts.Content: Communicate this to your doctor.  When I was having implants put in due to bc, my plastic surgeon brought out three size implants, small, medium and large and left me alone and then returned and asked me what I wanted.  I always had small breasts and the opportunity to enlarge was tempting but after having bc I just wanted to look normal again.  I opted for the smalls and have been happy with my decision.  Again communicate your wishes.
Posts.Title: tissue expanders

Posts.Content: Hi Linda!  Looks like you ended up in the wrong category, your posting is under breast cancer instead thyroid. Lucky, I have had both so I came to this sight.  I'm do for thryoid surgery on the 31st of July so I haven't experienced being hypo as yet but I would ask your endocrinologist if there is something you can take for the aches.  As for the water retention, I understand all your body functions that are normally controlled by your thyroid slows down.  I read somewhere that this includes you kidney function and that is were the water retention comes in but it is only temporary until you are able to be regulated with hormone so it doesn't have any residual effect. That is my understanding anyway but here again your endo's office should be able to answer any questions or concerns you are having.  Hope this helps!
Posts.Title: New here, with questions?

Posts.Content: This is the first time I found you log but I want to say how sorry I am for your loss.  Janet sounds like she was a spirited person and I'm sure her spirit will live on.  I'm sorry she was so young.  I was diagnosed with BC at 54 and am dealing with a 3rd cancer.  When I left my medical oncologist's office the other day I saw a young couple probably in their 40's.  He was pushing his loved one in a wheel chair.  She had a turben on her head so I know she was battling BC.  Her face was pretty but there was no smile.  I feel blessed that I was 54 and my two girls were pretty much on their own, one was still in college.  I know now they will do fine no matter.  I feel for younger women who are still raising their children or in some case haven't had the opportunity as yet.  I wear a pink band on my wrist just about every day.  I never want to forget that there are still women and some men out there who are given this diagnosis and have to fight until we have a cure.  God bless you for loving Janet and God bless Janet for her brave fight.
Posts.Title: we lost but we never gave up

Posts.Content: Yes, I think a lot of women would be interested in knowing what over the counter capsule is available to block estrogen.  I personally am taking Femara and tolerate it well but I have read scores of blogs where women are really suffering physically on the estrogen blocker meds but don't want to compromise the benefit it may have on their cancer.  Thanks!
Posts.Title: Caffeine and breast cancer

Posts.Content: I'm so sorry to hear you are going through this. I was diagnosed in Sept. 03 and after the initial shock I was like you, what next?? Since your doctor indicated you are a candidate for lumpectomy you will require radiation, it is a 2 step process, you either opt for mastectomy and no radiation or lumpectomy with. Radiation wasn't bad for me. I have very sensitive skin so I mentioned that to doc. and was given a radiation cream, Biafine. It worked wonders, just some pinkness that went away in a couple months. Did your doctor mention lymph node or sentinel node dissection? You will probably need one or the other, sentinel is the least invasive. This will determine if it has reached any of the lymph nodes. This information is needed as well as the size, grade, etc. which will determine your current stage and what treatment options are recommended. Also, you age is important as there are hormone therapies only post menapausal women can take. I know this all seems overwhelming so take it one step at a time. Ask questions, ask about options, get a second opinion if you do not feel comfortable with what is being offered to you. I had a second opinion and when he also agreed with the options being given I felt better. I felt better when I had some control over my own health so I sought out information as it was told to me. I did not have to have chemo as a 54 year old women with stage l, but I do take Femara, a hormonal therapy and have been fortunate enough to have not experienced side effects from the medication. One last point if it shows in one or two lymph nodes it is not a death sentence as in some cancers, it is still curable at this stage. And there are many woman living with breast cancer and going on with their lives. You are not alone. Best of luck as you go through this process and keep the faith.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed..so Now What...

Posts.Content: I had a partial mastectomy or extensive lympectomy with radiation 5 years ago for stage 1 BC, estrogen/progesterin positive.  I posed this question to my surgeon.  His response was if it reoccurred in the original breast I would face mastectomy with chemo.  If it occurred in the opposite breast I may be able to be treated with lumpectomy and radiation to that breast (don't know about chemo, probably).  He advised me that the same breast could not be radiated again.  Hopes this helps!
Posts.Title: biopsy - mri

Posts.Content: Many of us have gone through a similar experience.  I personally went through this 4 years ago this month.  It was a horror story.  The waiting and questionable information was the worse.  I remember at that time I felt as if my world had stopped and I was consumed with doctors, hospitals and medical terminology.  It was like the rest of the world was moving without me.  But I'm glad to say that will pass in do time and there is life after a breast cancer diagnosis.  I had another set back this year when I was diagnosed with thyroid cancer but for now I've been able to move past that as well.  People I know shake their heads in awe as to the bad luck I've experienced over the past years but I feel that I am stronger and a better person as a result of getting through all this, and using my experiences to help someone who is just facing or about to face this.  I would agree with one of the postings to take some time and educate yourself and get a 2nd even 3rd opinion.  I have even learned that it is a good idea to have a second pathologist confirm the findings.  At first it is all over whelming but once you get over the initial shock you can take action to be an active player in your own treatment and care.  I know this empowered me.  God bless you and things will get better.
Posts.Title: today changed my life
